summary_response.main_summary: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors convened its regular meeting on Tuesday, June 3, 2025. The meeting began with a roll call, confirming all eleven supervisors were present, followed by a land acknowledgment and the Pledge of Allegiance. The Clerk provided communications regarding public participation. The Board then proceeded to approve the minutes from previous meetings. A comprehensive consent agenda, comprising numerous routine items, was passed on first reading and finally adopted without any items being severed. The regular agenda saw several ordinances and resolutions passed on first reading or adopted, including significant financial authorizations and administrative code amendments. A key discussion involved the establishment of the San Francisco Downtown Revitalization and Economic Recovery Financing District, where an amendment was proposed, seconded, and adopted by unanimous consent before the main items were passed. The meeting also included committee reports, notably the renaming of a street to "Dr. Amos C. Brown Way" and the approval of a mayoral appointment to the Port Commission. A significant portion of the meeting was dedicated to a special order for commendations, honoring Police Chief Bill Scott, Captain Lisa Johansson, local business The Check In Lounge, community leader Michael Wong, and librarian Robert Carlson for their meritorious service. The public comment period featured numerous speakers addressing various concerns, including federal funding, solar permitting issues, cuts to soda tax-funded programs, and a proposed $5 tennis court reservation fee. The meeting concluded with the adoption of two resolutions without committee reference and a solemn adjournment in memory of several beloved individuals.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 1 ROLL CALL AND PLEDGE OF ALLEGIANCE
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The meeting commenced with a roll call conducted by the Madam Clerk, confirming the presence of all eleven members of the Board of Supervisors: Supervisor Chen (Connie), Supervisor Chen (Chin), Supervisor Dorsey, Supervisor Engardio, Supervisor Fielder, Supervisor Mahmood, Supervisor Mandelman (President), Supervisor Melgar, Supervisor Sadr, Supervisor Sheryl, and Supervisor Walton. Following the roll call, President Mandelman led the Board in a land acknowledgment, recognizing the unceded ancestral homeland of the Ramaytush Ohlone, and then led the Pledge of Allegiance.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 2 COMMUNICATIONS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Madam Clerk provided communications to the public, outlining how to attend the meeting in the Board's Legislative Chamber (City Hall, Room 250), watch proceedings on SFGovTV Channel 26 or livestream online, and submit written public comments via email or postal service. She also informed the public about how to request reasonable accommodations under the Americans with Disabilities Act or language assistance by contacting the Clerk's Office at least two business days in advance.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 3 APPROVAL OF MEETING MINUTES
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board considered the approval of the April 22nd, 2025, and April 29th, 2025, Regular Board Meeting Minutes, and the April 30th, 2025, Special Meeting Minutes of the Budget and Appropriations Committee, which constituted a quorum of the Board of Supervisors. No changes were proposed. A motion to approve the minutes as presented was made by Supervisor Melgar and seconded by Supervisor Sheryl. Upon a roll call vote, the minutes were approved with 11 Ayes (Mandelman: I, Melgar: I, Sadr: I, Sheryl: I, Walton: I, Chan: I, Chen: I, Dorsey: I, Engardio: I, Fielder: I, Mahmood: I). Without objection, the minutes were approved after public comment as presented.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 4 CONSENT AGENDA
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 1 through 8, which included a range of ordinances and resolutions, were presented on the Consent Agenda, considered routine and subject to removal if a member objected. No items were severed, though Supervisor Sheryl requested to be added as a co-sponsor on Item 3 (250439). Upon a roll call vote, all items on the Consent Agenda passed with 11 Ayes (Mandelman: I, Melgar: I, Sadr: I, Sheryl: I, Walton: I, Chan: I, Chen: I, Dorsey: I, Engardio: I, Fielder: I, Mahmood: I). Without objection, the ordinances were passed on first reading, and the resolutions were finally passed.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250386 Authorizing Refunding Certificates of Participation - U.S. Bank Trust Company, National Association - Multiple Capital Improvement Projects
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, authorized the execution and delivery of Certificates of Participation (COPs) in one or more series to prepay rental payments due to U.S. Bank Trust Company National Association as successor project trustee. It also approved multiple forms of agreements, leases, leaseback notices, and a purchase contract between the City and one or more initial purchasers of the certificates. This item was passed on first reading as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250387 Appropriation - $379,000,000 Including $350,000,000 Series 2025R Certificates of Participation Refunding Proceeds and $29,000,000 of Series 2017B Prior Debt Reserve Proceeds - FY2024-2025
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, appropriated $379 million, consisting of $350 million from Refunding Certificates of Participation Series 2025R proceeds and $29 million from Series 2017B prior debt service reserve. These funds were appropriated to the Refunding Certificates of Participation Series 2025R and placed on the Controller's Reserve pending the sale of the Certificates of Participation in Fiscal Years 2024 through 2025. This item was passed on first reading as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250439 Administrative Code - Assessment Appeals Board Fees
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was an ordinance to amend the Administrative Code to increase various Assessment Appeals Board fees, including administrative processing fees, hearing fees, and fees for written findings. Supervisor Sheryl was added as a co-sponsor for this item. This item was passed on first reading as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250449 Administrative Code - Fees for Farmers' Markets and the Alemany Flea Market
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was an ordinance to amend the Administrative Code to increase the fees for vendors to sell at City-operated Farmer's Markets and at the Alemany Flea Market. This item was passed on first reading as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250486 Appropriation - Fire Department - Ambulance Service Revenue - $7,931,338 - De-Appropriation and Appropriation - Various Departments - Permanent Salaries - $2,865,992 - Permanent Salaries/Overtime - $10,797,330 - FY2024-2025
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, involved multiple appropriations. It appropriated approximately $7.9 million of ambulance service revenue in the Fire Department, approximately $1.5 million in permanent salaries in the Department of Emergency Management, approximately $866,000 in the Fire Department, and $500,000 in the Public Utilities Commission. Additionally, it appropriated approximately $3.7 million to permanent salaries and approximately $5 million to overtime in the Fire Department, and $1.5 million to overtime in the Department of Emergency Management, and $500,000 to overtime in the Public Utilities Commission, all to support the departments' projected increases in overtime in Fiscal Year 2024 through 2025. This ordinance required a two-thirds vote of all members of the Board for approval of the Fire Department's appropriation of approximately $7.9 million. This item was passed on first reading as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote, meeting the two-thirds majority requirement.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250422 Accept and Expend Grant - Retroactive - California Department of Health Care Services - CalAIM JI PATH Round 3 Funding - $1,500,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was a resolution to retroactively authorize the Adult Probation Department to accept and expend a $1.5 million grant from the California Department of Health Care Services for a statewide program entitled CalAIM JI PATH Round 3 Funding for the term of January 31st, 2025, through June 30th, 2026. This item was adopted as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250450 Airport Professional Services Agreement - T.Y. Lin International - Capital Program Support Services for Capital Improvement Plan - Further Modifications Not to Exceed $40,000,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was a resolution to approve the second modification to an Airport Contract for Capital Program Support Services for the Capital Improvement Plan for the San Francisco International Airport with T.Y. Lin International. The modification increased the contract amount by $32 million for a new total contract amount of $40 million and extended the contract for an additional four years of service through September 29th, 2029. This item was adopted as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250457 Grant Agreement Amendment - Episcopal Community Services - Master Lease Hotels - Not to Exceed $72,297,684
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was a resolution to approve the second amendment to the grant agreement with Episcopal Community Services for support services, property management, and master list stewardship at the Alder, the Crosby, the Elm, the Hillsdale, and the Minton Hotels for permanent supportive housing for formerly homeless adults. The amendment extended the grant term by 424 months (now through June 30th, 2027) and increased the agreement amount by approximately $25 million for a new total amount of approximately $72.2 million. This item was adopted as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250458 Grant Agreement Amendment - Five Keys Schools and Programs - Next Door Shelter - Emergency Shelter Operations - Not to Exceed $59,204,930
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was a resolution to approve the third amendment to the grant agreement with Five Keys Schools and Programs to provide emergency shelter operations and services at Next Door Shelter. The amendment increased the grant amount by approximately $26.7 million for a new total of approximately $59.2 million and extended the grant agreement term by 36 months (now through June 30th, 2028). This item was adopted as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250459 Assignment and Assumption Agreement - The Tides Center - DISH SF - Lease and Property Management Agreement - 1321 Mission Street
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was a resolution to approve and authorize the Director of Property and the Executive Director of the Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing to approve the assignment of a certain lease and property management agreement dated February 17th, 2023, by and between the City and The Tides Center (as fiscal sponsor to deliver innovation in support of housing for the real property located at 1321 Mission Street) from Tides to DISH S.F., a nonprofit public benefit corporation, to become effective July 1st, 2025. This item was adopted as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250493 Grant Agreement Amendment - Chinatown SROS, L.L.C. - 1005 Powell Street - Not to Exceed $6,781,969
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was a resolution that approved the execution of a first amendment to the Senior Operating Subsidy Grant Agreement with Chinatown SROs LLC. The amendment increased the grant amount by $572,000 for a new total grant amount of $6.7 million to fully fund the 15-year and six-month term through June 30th, 2039, with rent subsidy for 35 extremely low-income seniors at 1005 Powell Street, a 64-unit 100% affordable multifamily rental housing development. This item was adopted as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250496 Issuance and Sale of Revenue Obligations - California Enterprise Development Authority - California Institute of Integral Studies - Not to Exceed $15,000,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was a resolution to approve, for the purposes of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, the issuance and sale of revenue obligations by the California Enterprise Development Authority in an aggregate principal amount of $15 million to finance or refinance the cost of acquisition, construction, installation, rehabilitation, equipping, and furnishing of various capital facilities to be owned and operated by the California Institute of Integral Studies, a California nonprofit public benefit corporation. This item was adopted as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250408 Cost of Living Adjustment - Budget and Legislative Analyst Services - $3,392,249 - FY2025-2026
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, part of the Consent Agenda, was a motion to enact a 4.50% Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA) for the base fiscal year of 2024 through 2025 contract amount of approximately $3.2 million for Budget and Legislative Analyst Services. This adjustment is to be effectuated as of July 1st, 2025, resulting in a new Fiscal Year 2025-2026 contract amount of $3.4 million, an annual increase of $146,000, and a new total contract amount of $36 million for the contract term ending December 31st, 2031. This item was approved as part of the Consent Agenda with an 11-0 vote.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250423 Resolution of Intention to Establish San Francisco Downtown Revitalization and Economic Recovery Financing District
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, considered together with Item 23, was a Resolution of Intention to establish the San Francisco Downtown Revitalization and Economic Recovery Financing District. The district aims to finance commercial-to-residential conversion projects and other authorized costs, determine district boundaries, state the need for the district and its goals, describe the use of property tax revenue for district activities, authorize the establishment of a time and date for a public hearing on the plan, and make appropriate findings. This resolution was adopted by unanimous consent ('Same House, Same Call') after an amendment to Item 23 was approved.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250424 Administrative Code - Establishing the Board of Directors - San Francisco Downtown Revitalization and Economic Recovery Financing District
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, considered together with Item 22, was an Ordinance to amend the Administrative Code to establish and define the membership and duties of the Board of Directors of the San Francisco Downtown Revitalization and Economic Recovery Financing District. Supervisor Dorsey expressed strong support for the district, highlighting its potential to incentivize adaptive reuse projects for housing and downtown revitalization. Supervisor Dorsey moved to amend the ordinance on page 6, line 8, subsection M, to add language stating: 'As permitted by the Downtown Revitalization Law, all costs incurred by any other City Department in connection with the creation, management, or other administrative support for the Downtown Revitalization District shall be paid by the Downtown Revitalization District.' The motion to amend was seconded by Supervisor Chan and approved by unanimous consent. The amended ordinance was then passed on first reading by unanimous consent ('Same House, Same Call').

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250454 Administrative Code - Waiving Contracting Requirements for a Port Lease - CAST at Large LLC
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was an ordinance to waive the contracting requirements of the Administrative Code for tenant improvements performed by KARST at Large LLC, a prospective Port tenant or its agents, for the lease with the Port of San Francisco for property at Pier 29, which was approved by the Port Commission. The ordinance was passed on first reading by unanimous consent ('Same House, Same Call').

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250523 Resolution of Intention - Street Name Change - Pierce Street from Fulton Street to Golden Gate Avenue - "Dr. Amos C. Brown Way"
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, considered together with Item 26, was a resolution to declare the intention of the Board to rename the 800-900 blocks of Pierce Street from Fulton Street to Golden Gate Avenue to 'Dr. Amos C. Brown Way,' in recognition of Dr. Amos C. Brown's lifetime of leadership in civil rights and community building. A roll call vote was requested due to a supervisor leaving the chamber. The resolution was adopted with 11 Ayes (Mandelman: I, Melgar: I, Sadr: I, Sheryl: I, Walton: I, Chan: I, Chen: I, Dorsey: I, Engardio: I, Fielder: I, Mahmood: I).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250524 Commemorative Street Name Designation - Pierce Street from Fulton Street to Golden Gate Avenue - "Dr. Amos C. Brown Way"
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, considered together with Item 25, was a resolution to add the commemorative street name 'Dr. Amos C. Brown Way' to the 800-900 blocks of Pierce Street from Fulton Street to Golden Gate Avenue, recognizing Dr. Amos C. Brown's contributions. A roll call vote was requested due to a supervisor leaving the chamber. The resolution was adopted with 11 Ayes (Mandelman: I, Melgar: I, Sadr: I, Sheryl: I, Walton: I, Chan: I, Chen: I, Dorsey: I, Engardio: I, Fielder: I, Mahmood: I).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250526 Apply to Amend San Francisco's Priority Conservation Areas Designations
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, forwarded as a committee report from the Land Use and Transportation Committee, was a resolution to authorize the Planning Department to apply on behalf of the City and County to confirm existing and create new and revised designations of Priority Conservation Areas by the Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG) and the Metropolitan Transportation Commission (MTC). The resolution was adopted by unanimous consent ('Same House, Same Call').

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250506 Mayoral Appointment, Port Commission - Ken McNeely
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, forwarded as a committee report from the Rules Committee, was a motion to approve the Mayor's nomination for the appointment of Ken McNeely to the Port Commission for a term ending May 1st, 2029. The item's title was amended by the committee, striking the word 'Rejecting' from its original form. The motion was approved by unanimous consent ('Same House, Same Call').

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 7 SPECIAL ORDER 2:30 P.M. - Recognition of Commendations
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board held a special order at 2:30 P.M. to recognize and commend individuals for meritorious service to the City and County of San Francisco. This session included heartfelt tributes and remarks from various supervisors and the honorees themselves. The commendations included: Police Chief Bill Scott for his eight years of transformative leadership and reform; Captain Lisa Johansson for her exceptional community engagement and leadership at Mission Station; Rich Zavala and Jeff Scott, owners of The Check In Lounge, for creating a welcoming LGBTQ-owned community hub; Michael Wong for his three decades of dedicated service to vulnerable communities through victim advocacy and community building; and Robert Carlson for his extensive career and innovative contributions to the San Francisco Public Library system.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 9 ROLL CALL FOR INTRODUCTIONS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
During the roll call for introductions of new business, several supervisors presented new legislation and requests for adjournment in memory of individuals:

*   **Supervisor Randleman** submitted legislation and requested adjournment in memory of Steve Kellerman, who passed away at age 83, highlighting his community involvement, professional career in affirmative action, and philanthropic cycling.
*   **Supervisor Melgar** introduced legislation to ease the filling of vacant storefronts by eliminating size caps in certain commercial districts (requiring conditional use authorization) and removing conditional use requirements for subdividing spaces that move closer to code conformity. She also announced her request to Budget Chair Chan to hold funding for the San Francisco Zoological Society in reserve pending cooperation with an audit.
*   **Supervisor Chen (Chin)** introduced a resolution urging Governor Newsom and the California Senate Budget Chair to fully restore the optional adult acupuncture benefit in Medi-Cal, emphasizing its importance as a non-pharmacological alternative. She also submitted a Letter of Inquiry to the San Francisco Planning Department, formally requesting a detailed implementation plan and timeline for a publicly accessible modeling tool to evaluate the Housing Element rezoning proposal's impacts on neighborhoods and housing goals.
*   **Supervisor Dorsey** requested adjournment in memory of Sharon Ardoin, a beloved former member of the San Francisco City Attorney's Office, who served the city for 26 years and was known for her warmth, grace, and loyalty.
*   **Supervisor Mahmood** requested adjournment in memory of Captain Julio Dominic De Lucci, a San Francisco Fire Department veteran who passed away at age 60 after a battle with pancreatic cancer, highlighting his 25 years of service, teaching abilities, and final act of kindness in giving up a promotion.
*   **Supervisor Sheryl** introduced a resolution recognizing June 6th as National Gun Violence Awareness Day in San Francisco, emphasizing the impact of gun violence and the city's progress in prevention. She also introduced a resolution urging the SFPD and Department of Emergency Management to classify all 911 calls regarding illicit drug activity within 1500 feet of parks, playgrounds, and schools as Priority A emergencies. Finally, she requested adjournment in memory of William Joseph Heep, a beloved District Two community member and volunteer for the Lafayette Park Conservation Program.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 10 PUBLIC COMMENT
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
The Board opened the floor for public comment, allowing speakers to address the approval of minutes, items for adoption without committee reference (Items 31 and 32), or general matters. Each speaker was allotted two minutes.

*   **Chris Ward Klein** discussed the city's eligibility for federal funds, issues with the City Attorney's office, potential layoffs, and cyberstalking.
*   **John Paul Up and Jani (Sutro Power)** pleaded for the Board to address backsliding on clean energy goals due to problematic solar and battery permitting processes.
*   **Faith Sanchez (Glide Center for Social Justice)** urged against cutting funding for soda tax-funded programs, specifically the Glide Social Justice Academy, emphasizing its importance for marginalized communities.
*   **Justin (Mission Athletic Club)** opposed the proposed $5/hour tennis court reservation fee, arguing it creates financial barriers and questioned the integrity of its proponents.
*   **Elaina (Mission Athletic Club)** echoed opposition to the $5 fee, highlighting its burden on communities.
*   **Ian James (Glide Center for Social Justice)** expressed devastation over proposed soda tax funding cuts, stressing the vital role of community-based organizations.
*   **Apple Kronk (Glide Social Justice Academy)** shared a personal testimony of how the Social Justice Academy aided her recovery from homelessness and substance use, urging continued funding.
*   **Linda Mantell (Glide Memorial Church)** urged against cutting funds for the Glide Center for Social Justice.
*   **Toby Sachs Quintana (Mission Athletic Club)** opposed the $5 court fee, citing its impact on various demographics and questioning the financial backing.
*   **May (Mission Athletic Club)** opposed the $5 fee, stating it would deter new players and go against the spirit of public parks.
*   **Argin (Mission Athletic Club)** opposed the $5 fee, reiterating concerns about financial burden and the credibility of its proponents.
*   **Dr. Dina Abdo (Mission Athletic Club)** opposed the $5 fee from a public health perspective, emphasizing the importance of free access to physical activity.
*   **Belinda Hong (Mission Athletic Club)** opposed the $5 fee, highlighting how free access fosters inclusivity and community stewardship.
*   **Jason Prado (Mission Athletic Club)** opposed the $5 fee, arguing it commercializes public spaces and diminishes community feeling.
*   **Prince Boucher (Mission Athletic Club)** opposed the $5 fee, detailing the club's success in promoting civic wellness through free services and arguing the fee is counterproductive.
*   An **unidentified speaker** condemned nationalism and America's war crimes, specifically the execution of Jonathan Joss, sharing a statement from his husband.
*   **Christopher Maguire** supported Supervisor Walton's resolution opposing state cuts to Medi-Cal for undocumented adults.
*   An **unidentified speaker** supported gun violence prevention and opposed the $5 tennis court fee.
*   **Michael Rupak (Latinx Democratic Club)** urged the Board to swiftly pass a resolution opposing Governor Newsom's proposed Medi-Cal cuts.
*   **Richard Rusty Peterson** discussed communications with notable citizens and warned against future parcel taxes on large corporations.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 12 FOR ADOPTION WITHOUT COMMITTEE REFERENCE
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 31 and 32 were introduced for adoption without reference to committee, requiring a unanimous vote for adoption of a resolution on first reading. Alternatively, a member could require a resolution on first reading to go to committee. No one requested to sever any items. Upon a roll call vote, both resolutions were adopted with 11 Ayes (Mandelman: I, Melgar: I, Sadr: I, Sheryl: I, Walton: I, Chan: I, Chen: I, Dorsey: I, Engardio: I, Fielder: I, Mahmood: I). Without objection, the resolutions were adopted.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 13 IMPERATIVE AGENDA
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: There were no imperative agenda items reported.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 14 ADJOURNMENT
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
The meeting was adjourned in memory of several beloved individuals:
*   **Mr. Steve Kellerman** (on behalf of President Mandelman)
*   **Mr. William Joseph Heep** (on behalf of Supervisor Sheryl)
*   **Ms. Sharon Ardoin** (on behalf of Supervisor Dorsey)
*   **Captain Julio Dominic De Lucci** (at the request and on behalf of Supervisor Mahmood and President Mandelman, and on behalf of the entire Board of Supervisors). Fire Chief Chris Brown offered additional remarks in honor of Captain De Lucci, highlighting his legacy as a teacher and his final act of kindness.

summary_response.main_summary:
The San Francisco Board of Supervisors held its regular meeting on Tuesday, June 10, 2025. The meeting commenced with a roll call, establishing a quorum, followed by a land acknowledgment and the Pledge of Allegiance. Supervisor Fielder was excused from the meeting due to absence. A significant portion of the meeting was dedicated to the Mayor's appearance, where Mayor Daniel Lurie addressed ongoing federal immigration enforcement actions and introduced new legislation to tackle RV homelessness, emphasizing citywide parking limits alongside expanded outreach and housing services. Formal policy discussions ensued, focusing on the city's shelter system and the need for community-responsive capital investment projects in historically neglected areas.

The Board then proceeded with routine business, including the approval of past meeting minutes and the consent agenda, which saw several ordinances and resolutions passed. Unfinished business items, largely financial appropriations, administrative code amendments, and grant/lease approvals, were also addressed and passed. A special order of business at 2:30 PM was dedicated to recognizing meritorious service, with commendations presented to student organizers of a donation drive, a beloved Muni transit operator, a pioneer of anime and manga in America, and San Francisco's first Drag Laureate.

Later, the Board adopted several resolutions and motions, including those related to public health grants, transportation contracts, and mayoral appointments to various commissions. Committee reports from the Government Audit and Oversight Committee were also approved, covering compensation for unrepresented employees, a memorandum of understanding, assessment ballots for benefit districts, and a performance audit of the Recreation and Park Department. New business was introduced by several supervisors, proposing resolutions on language access, condemning ICE abductions, affirming protest rights, and requesting inquiries into the 311 mobile app. The meeting concluded with general public comment, where citizens addressed a range of issues, and a final adoption of items without committee reference, followed by adjournments in memory of Shawn O'Neal McGrew and Louisa Poole.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 1 ROLL CALL AND PLEDGE OF ALLEGIANCE
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The meeting was called to order by President Mandelman. The Madam Clerk conducted a roll call, confirming the presence of Supervisors Chan, Chen, Dorsey, Engardio, Mahmood, Mandelman, Melgar, Sadr, Sherald, and Walton, establishing a quorum. Supervisor Fielder was noted as not present. The Board then acknowledged that they were on the unceded ancestral homeland of the Ramaytush Ohlone people. Following this, the Pledge of Allegiance was recited. A communication was received from Supervisor Fielder requesting to be excused. A motion to excuse Supervisor Fielder was made by Supervisor Chen and seconded by Supervisor Mahmood. The Madam Clerk called the roll on the motion: Supervisor Melgar (Aye), Supervisor Sadr (Aye), Supervisor Sherald (Aye), Supervisor Walton (Aye), Supervisor Chan (Aye), Supervisor Chen (Aye), Supervisor Dorsey (Aye), Supervisor Engardio (Aye), Supervisor Mahmood (Aye), and Supervisor Mandelman (Aye). With ten 'Ayes' and no objections, Supervisor Fielder was excused from the meeting. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the simple majority requirement for procedural motions under Robert's Rules of Order.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 3 SPECIAL ORDER 2:00 P.M. - Mayor's Appearance Before The Board[Mayor Appearance Boiler 01-2013|B1,B2]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
Mayor Daniel Lurie appeared before the Board for a formal policy discussion. He began with opening remarks, addressing ongoing federal immigration enforcement actions downtown, emphasizing the city's sanctuary policies and the activation of the Emergency Operations Center. He then introduced new legislation, co-sponsored by Supervisors Melgar, Mandelman, Engardio, Dorsey, and Sherald, to tackle RV homelessness. This legislation proposes citywide parking limits of two hours for oversize vehicles and expands outreach, prioritizing housing and services over mere enforcement, building on the 'Breaking the Cycle' plan and a budget proposal to unlock $90 million for interim housing capacity.

Supervisor Walton (District 10) initiated the first topic, 'Shelters,' questioning the Mayor about the urgent need for permanent solutions to homelessness, particularly regarding the expansion of the tiny home site on Jerrold Street in District 10 without community buy-in. Mayor Lurie responded by highlighting the Jerrold Commons site as a critical part of the 'Breaking the Cycle' initiative, providing 60 cabins for older adults and proposing an expansion for 82 more beds. He emphasized community engagement efforts and the lack of complaints received via a public phone line. Supervisor Walton followed up, reiterating the community's lack of support for the Jerrold Street shelter expansion and challenging the Mayor's claim of collaborative decision-making, pointing out the absence of proposed shelters in other areas of the city. Mayor Lurie affirmed his commitment to working with the community and other supervisors on shelter placement across the city, stating his belief that the RV legislation would benefit Bayview residents.

Supervisor Chen (District 11) initiated the second topic, 'Centering Community Needs in Capital Investment Projects,' asking what processes the Mayor's office is implementing to ensure major capital investments in historically neglected parts of the city, such as the Ingleside Police Station and Ocean View Library, are responsive to community needs. Mayor Lurie responded by outlining the city's biennial ten-year Capital Plan process, which prioritizes equity and community input throughout planning, design, and construction. He specifically mentioned the community room in the new Ingleside Police Station and the shift to a full rebuild for the Ocean View Library based on community feedback. Supervisor Chen followed up by requesting the Mayor's commitment to work directly with her in District 11 to engage constituents on these major investments. Mayor Lurie affirmed his commitment. The Mayor declined to ask a question to the Supervisors, concluding the formal policy discussion, which was then filed after general public comment.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 2 COMMUNICATIONS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Madam Clerk provided information on how the public can attend and participate in Board meetings. This included details on attending in person at City Hall Room 250, watching on SFGovTV Channel 26 or online at www.sfgovtv.org, and submitting public comment via email to BOS.Clerk@sfgov.org or by postal service to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, City Hall Room 244. Information on requesting reasonable accommodations under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) or language assistance by contacting the Clerk's office at least two business days in advance via phone (415-554-5184) was also provided.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 3 APPROVAL OF MEETING MINUTES
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The minutes from the May 6th, 2025 Board meeting were presented for approval. No changes were proposed by any Board member. A motion to approve the minutes as presented was made by Supervisor Chen and seconded by Supervisor Sherald. The Madam Clerk called the roll: Supervisor Melgar (Aye), Supervisor Sadr (Aye), Supervisor Sherald (Aye), Supervisor Walton (Aye), Supervisor Chan (Aye), Supervisor Chen (Aye), Supervisor Dorsey (Aye), Supervisor Engardio (Aye), Supervisor Mahmood (Aye), and Supervisor Mandelman (Aye). With ten 'Ayes' and no objections, the minutes were approved, to be formally adopted after public comment. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the simple majority requirement for procedural motions under Robert's Rules of Order.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 4 CONSENT AGENDA[Consent Boiler|B1]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 2 through 9 were presented as the Consent Agenda, meaning they were considered routine and could be approved collectively without individual discussion unless a member objected. No objections were raised by any Board member. The Madam Clerk called the roll on the Consent Agenda: Supervisor Melgar (Aye), Supervisor Sadr (Aye), Supervisor Sherald (Aye), Supervisor Walton (Aye), Supervisor Chan (Aye), Supervisor Chen (Aye), Supervisor Dorsey (Aye), Supervisor Engardio (Aye), Supervisor Mahmood (Aye), and Supervisor Mandelman (Aye). With ten 'Ayes' and no objections, these ordinances were finally passed. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the simple majority requirement for standard legislation under the San Francisco City Charter.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250486 Appropriation - Fire Department - Ambulance Service Revenue - $7,931,338 - De-Appropriation and Appropriation - Various Departments - Permanent Salaries - $2,865,992 - Permanent Salaries/Overtime - $10,797,330 - FY2024-2025
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Item 10, an ordinance to appropriate approximately $7.9 million of ambulance service revenue in the Fire Department, and to appropriate approximately $1.5 million in permanent salaries in the Department of Emergency Management, approximately $866,000 in the Fire Department, and $500,000 in the Public Utilities Commission, and to appropriate approximately $3.7 million to permanent salaries and approximately $5 million to overtime in the Fire Department, approximately $1.5 million to overtime in the Department of Emergency Management, and $500,000 to overtime in the Public Utilities Commission, in order to support the departments' projected increases in overtime in Fiscal Years 2024 through 2025, was presented. The Madam Clerk noted that this ordinance requires a two-thirds vote of all members of the Board for approval of the Fire Department's appropriation of approximately $7.9 million. The item was taken 'same house, same call,' indicating that all Supervisors present voted in favor. Without objection, the ordinance was finally passed. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, which is sufficient for a two-thirds vote given 11 members on the Board and one excused.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 7 SPECIAL ORDER 2:30 P.M. - Recognition of Commendations
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
The Board proceeded with the recognition of commendations for meritorious service to the City and County of San Francisco.

Supervisor Melgar (District 7) honored the student organizers of St. Cecilia's Church and School's Socks, Shoes, and Sweats Donation Drive: Madelyn Mowbray, Patrick James McCauley, Gianna Monk, Reese Roland, Ava and Alexandra Gonzalez, Liam Kearney, and Mary Sinus, along with their advisor Jean Roland. The students spoke, expressing their gratitude and the impact of their community service project.

Supervisor Walton (District 10) celebrated Mac Allen, a beloved Muni Transit Operator from the Woods Division. Mac Allen was recognized for his warmth, attentiveness, and joy, as well as his poetry and advocacy for public transit. Mac Allen spoke, reading a poem he shared with Willie Brown Middle School students and advocating for proper funding for Muni.

Supervisor Mahmood (District 5) recognized Mr. Takashi Onishi, the founder of Japan Video and Media, for his profound influence on Japantown's cultural and commercial life and his pioneering role in introducing anime and manga to America. Mr. Onishi spoke, reflecting on his 40 years of business and his contributions to Japantown's cultural events.

Supervisor Dorsey (District 8) presented a special commendation to D'Arcy Drollinger, San Francisco's first Drag Laureate. D'Arcy Drollinger was honored for their work as an actor, writer, director, choreographer, producer, and entrepreneur, including founding Oasis and Oasis Arts, and initiatives like 'Meals on Heels.' D'Arcy Drollinger spoke, expressing humility and pride in representing the art of drag and the LGBTQ+ community, emphasizing the importance of community and the fight for fundamental rights.

This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the simple majority requirement for standard legislation under the San Francisco City Charter.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250369 Assessment Ballots for City Parcels - Ocean Avenue Community Benefit District
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Item 30, a resolution to authorize the Mayor or his designee to cast assessment ballots in the affirmative for the proposed renewal and expansion for two Property and Business Improvement Districts with respect to certain parcels of real property owned by the City subject to assessment in the Ocean Avenue Community Benefit District, was presented. This item was considered with Item 31. The items were taken 'same house, same call,' indicating that all Supervisors present voted in favor. Without objection, the resolutions were adopted. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the simple majority requirement for resolutions under the San Francisco City Charter.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250469 Assessment Ballots for City Parcels - Dogpatch and Northwest Potrero Hill Green Benefit District
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Item 31, a resolution to authorize the Mayor or his designee to cast assessment ballots in the affirmative for the proposed renewal and expansion for two Property and Business Improvement Districts with respect to certain parcels of real property owned by the City subject to assessment in the Dogpatch and Northwest Potrero Hill Green Benefit District, was presented as a committee report, recommended as amended with the same title. This item was considered with Item 30. The items were taken 'same house, same call,' indicating that all Supervisors present voted in favor. Without objection, the resolutions were adopted. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the simple majority requirement for resolutions under the San Francisco City Charter.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250430 Behested Payment Waiver - Economic Revitalization Efforts
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Item 32, a resolution to authorize the Mayor, members of the Mayor's Office, and the Director of the Office of Economic and Workforce Development to solicit donations from nonprofits, private organizations, grant makers, foundations, and other persons and entities for the purpose of supporting the continued economic revitalization of San Francisco for six months from the effective date of this resolution, notwithstanding the Behest of Payment Ordinance, was presented as a committee report. The item was taken 'same house, same call,' indicating that all Supervisors present voted in favor. Without objection, the resolution was adopted. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the simple majority requirement for resolutions under the San Francisco City Charter.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250551 Amending the Budget and Legislative Analyst Services Audit Plan - Recreation and Park Department - FY2025-2026
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Item 33, a motion to direct the Budget and Legislative Analyst to initiate a performance audit in Fiscal Year 2025 through 2026 of the Recreation and Park Department, was presented as a committee report. The item was taken 'same house, same call,' indicating that all Supervisors present voted in favor. Without objection, the motion was approved. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the simple majority requirement for motions under Robert's Rules of Order.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 9 ROLL CALL FOR INTRODUCTIONS [Roll Call Boiler|B1, B2]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
New business was introduced by several Supervisors:

Supervisor Melgar submitted legislation.

Supervisor Sadr submitted legislation.

Supervisor Sherald submitted legislation.

Supervisor Walton introduced a resolution in support of AB 1242, authored by Assembly Member Stephanie Wynn, which aims to strengthen California's language access laws for people with limited English proficiency and those who are deaf or hard of hearing. The rest of her legislation was submitted.

Supervisor Chan announced the adjournment of today's meeting in memory of Shawn O'Neal McGrew, a former General Manager of the Mill Valley Recreation Department and a long-serving Recreation Director at the San Francisco Recreation and Park Department. The rest of his legislation was submitted.

Supervisor Chen introduced a resolution condemning the abductions of immigrants by the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency, citing recent military-style operations in San Francisco and Los Angeles. She also announced the adjournment of today's meeting in memory of Louisa Poole, a fearless leader in the Asian American labor movement and the first American to be elected Executive Vice President of SEIU. The rest of her legislation was submitted.

Supervisor Dorsey submitted legislation.

Supervisor Engardio submitted legislation.

Supervisor Mahmood introduced a resolution affirming the public's right to peacefully assemble and protest actions of the federal government, condemning the militarization of civilian response to peaceful protests, and reaffirming San Francisco's commitment to immigrant justice and the City's Sanctuary Ordinance. He also introduced two Letters of Inquiry regarding the 311 mobile app, seeking improvements to data accuracy and system usability. The rest of his legislation was submitted.

President Mandelman submitted his legislation.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 10 PUBLIC COMMENT [Public Comment Boiler|B1, B2, N1]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
The Board opened the floor for general public comment on matters not on the agenda but within the Board's subject matter jurisdiction, as well as on the Mayor's appearance and the meeting minutes. Speakers were allotted two minutes each.

One speaker discussed '5G nefarious doorbells' and 'towers' installed across the country, issuing an ultimatum to remove them by July 1st.

Another speaker, Chris Ward Klein, spoke about Sergeant Klein of the United States Marine Corps, alleging that police department officials are not arresting the right people, leading to violence and riots. He claimed vehicles outside the Fire Department were reverse-engineering signal intelligence to cause violence and invited San Francisco to join a class-action lawsuit against 'state-sponsored terrorism.'

A speaker named Shane Michael Sleep discussed being 'strangled for 35 minutes' in San Francisco and criticized Christina Tulloch and certain officers for attempting to refuse his constitutional rights. He also mentioned a previous incident where he was laughed at for discussing his freedom being 'stolen' and criticized the city's police budget and non-resident officers.

Another speaker, who had just come from protests at Montgomery Street regarding ICE, described witnessing a 'kidnaping' by masked agents in an unmarked van, expressing horror at the aggressive driving into protesters and the lack of communication with the detained person. They highlighted the fear among immigrant families attending ICE court.

An individual spoke about being 'tortured for six years,' a victim of violence and illegal eviction, and being 'kidnaped' and 'beaten for seven hours' at a hospital as an epileptic and disabled person. They called for people with education and integrity to address these issues and for recognition of people's need for safety.

Ira Duffy commented on the Taylor Street construction, noting that despite improvements, the block remains the 'narrowest sidewalk in the downtown area' due to added furniture, making it difficult to navigate and contributing to homeless congregation.

A speaker inquired about putting a law on the November ballot regarding police not checking a database, expressing nervousness about speaking on TV and requesting to speak with staff after the meeting.

Ms. Brown spoke about the recent death of Sly Stone, leader of Sly and the Family Stone, and suggested recognizing the group's diversity. She also proposed turning the Nordstrom area in the City Mall into a supper club, managed by a Las Vegas entrepreneur, as a 'greatest idea of all' to revitalize the mid-market center.

Ms. Brown returned to speak about the lack of rewards being paid out for unsolved homicides, displaying pictures of her murdered son and other victims, pleading for the Board to pass legislation on January 17th and 24th to address this issue and provide justice for mothers like herself.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 12 FOR ADOPTION WITHOUT COMMITTEE REFERENCE[For Adoption Boiler|B1,B2]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 36 and 37 were introduced for adoption without reference to committee. A unanimous vote is required for adoption of a resolution on first reading today, or a member may require a resolution to go to committee. No members requested to sever any items. The Madam Clerk called the roll on Items 36 and 37: Supervisor Melgar (Aye), Supervisor Sadr (Aye), Supervisor Sherald (Aye), Supervisor Walton (Aye), Supervisor Chan (Aye), Supervisor Chen (Aye), Supervisor Dorsey (Aye), Supervisor Engardio (Aye), Supervisor Mahmood (Aye), and Supervisor Mandelman (Aye). With ten 'Ayes' and no objections, the resolution was adopted and the motion was approved. This vote passed with a 10-vote majority, meeting the unanimous vote requirement for adoption without committee reference, given the 10 Supervisors present.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 14 ADJOURNMENT
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The meeting was adjourned in memory of two individuals: Mr. Shawn O'Neal McGrew, on behalf of Supervisor Chan and noted by Supervisors Walton and Chan, and Miss Louisa Poole, on behalf of Supervisor Chen and a motion made by the Board President on behalf of the entire Board of Supervisors.
