summary_response.main_summary: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors convened its regular meeting on Tuesday, July 8, 2025. The meeting began with a roll call, land acknowledgment of the Ramaytush Ohlone, and the Pledge of Allegiance. Following communications from the Clerk, Mayor Daniel Lurie delivered a special address, summarizing his first six months in office and highlighting collaborations with various Supervisors on key city initiatives. The Board then approved the June 3, 2025, meeting minutes and passed two consent agenda items. A significant portion of the meeting was dedicated to the introduction of the City's Budget (Items 3-32) for Fiscal Years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027, which, after technical amendments, was continued to the July 15, 2025, meeting. Several ordinances were passed on first reading via unanimous consent. A special commendation was presented to Sam Mogannam of By Rite Market for his contributions to San Francisco's food culture and community. Committee reports from the Rules Committee regarding presidential appointments were approved. During the roll call for new business, Supervisor Sadr called for a hearing on the Central Subway's performance and extension. General public comment followed, covering a range of topics including sanctuary city status, unsolved homicides, budget priorities, surveillance, and enforcement of restraining orders. The Board then entered a closed session to discuss litigation with Pacific Gas and Electric Company, with no action taken and deliberations remaining confidential. A major special order of business was the Committee of the Whole hearing for the renewal and expansion of the Ocean Avenue Community Benefit District. After presentations from city staff and the CBD's executive director, and extensive public comment both for and against the proposal, an amendment to adjust the district boundaries was approved. Following the tabulation of weighted ballots, which showed no majority protest, the resolution to establish the renewed and expanded CBD was adopted. The meeting concluded after addressing several resolutions for adoption without committee reference, including one celebrating the resolution of a dispute between UC Health and Blue Shield of California, and another urging relief for businesses affected by the Islais Creek Bridge project.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 1 ROLL CALL AND PLEDGE OF ALLEGIANCE
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The meeting commenced with a roll call, confirming all members of the Board of Supervisors were present. Board President Mandelman then delivered an acknowledgment of the Ramaytush Ohlone, the original inhabitants of the San Francisco Peninsula, recognizing their ancestral homeland and affirming their sovereign rights. This was followed by the recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance. The Board also acknowledged the staff of SFGovTV, specifically Kaleena Mendoza, for their work in recording meetings and making transcripts available to the public.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 2 COMMUNICATIONS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Madam Clerk provided several communications to the Board and the public. She announced the 2:00 P.M. Special Order for the Mayor's appearance. She informed the public about various ways to watch the proceedings, including SFGovTV's Channel 26 and live streaming online. The Clerk also clarified that items 3 through 32, which comprise the City's budget, had already undergone public comment in committee and would not be open for public comment during this meeting. Instructions were provided for submitting written comments via email or postal service for other agenda items, and for requesting reasonable accommodations under the Americans with Disabilities Act or language assistance.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 3 APPROVAL OF MEETING MINUTES
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board considered the approval of the June 3, 2025, Board meeting minutes. A motion to approve the minutes as presented was made by Supervisor Chan and seconded by Supervisor Walton. Upon a roll call vote, all 11 Supervisors voted 'Aye'. In accordance with Robert's Rules of Order, the motion passed unanimously. The minutes were approved without objection, with the procedural note that they would be formally approved after public comment.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 4 CONSENT AGENDA
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 1 and 2 were presented on the Consent Agenda, which are considered routine and typically passed without separate discussion unless a member objects. Upon a roll call vote, all 11 Supervisors voted 'Aye'. The ordinances were declared finally passed without objection, indicating unanimous consent as per standard parliamentary procedure for consent agendas.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 6 NEW BUSINESS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This section introduced the City's Budget for Fiscal Years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027, comprising items 3 through 32. The Madam Clerk read out the titles of all 30 budget-related ordinances and resolutions, which included the Budget Appropriation Ordinance, Annual Salary Ordinance, and various amendments to the Administrative, Business and Tax Regulations, Health, Park, Public Works, and Planning Codes, as well as resolutions for grants, bond issuances, and expenditure plans. Pursuant to City Charter Section 9.100(b), the Board cannot adopt the budget earlier than July 15th nor later than August 1st. Supervisor Chan, as Budget Chair, introduced two technical amendments to the Board's Supervisors Budget Spending Plan: one to reduce funding for the Department of Children, Youth and Their Families through position adjustments and a non-journal reduction, and another to update language for a restoration line item to 'community stabilization and cultural development'. A motion to approve these amendments was made by Supervisor Chan and seconded by Supervisor Walton, passing without objection. Subsequently, a motion to continue all budget items (3-32) as amended to the Board's next meeting on July 15, 2025, was made by Supervisor Chan and seconded by Supervisor Dorsey. This motion passed with a unanimous roll call vote of 11 'Aye' votes, continuing the items without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250517 Park Code - Treasure Island, Yerba Buena Island, and Certain Additional Properties
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance proposed to amend the Park Code to apply its provisions to certain parks on Treasure Island and Yerba Buena Island, and to allow for the application of the Park Code to additional properties operated and managed by the Recreation and Parks Department, subject to Commission approval. The item was passed on First Reading by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent from the Board members present.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250538 Planning Code - Priority Processing for Certain Commercial Uses
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance proposed to amend the Planning Code to update eligibility requirements for the Priority Processing Program for certain commercial uses, including enabling formula retail use with fewer than 20 establishments to participate, and updating scheduling and extension requirements. The item was passed on First Reading by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent from the Board members present.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250540 Planning Code - Temporary Use Authorizations
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance proposed to amend the Planning Code to streamline and simplify the process for obtaining and extending temporary use authorizations, implement standards and requirements for such authorizations, permit seasonal political campaign offices for up to one year, and extend the maximum time for a pop-up retail temporary use to three years. The item was passed on First Reading by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent from the Board members present.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250541 Public Works, Administrative Codes - Café Tables and Chairs, Display Merchandise, Appurtenant Building Features, and Sidewalk Shared Spaces
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance proposed to amend the Public Works Code to streamline the approval of certain encroachments in the public right-of-way, establish a registration requirement in place of permit requirements and fees for cafe tables and chairs and display merchandise, and eliminate minor encroachment permit requirements and right-of-way occupancy fees for permanent building features. It also proposed to amend the Administrative Code to exempt cafe tables and chairs and display merchandise from the Shared Spaces Program. The item was passed on First Reading by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent from the Board members present.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250537 Police Code - Entertainment Permits
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance proposed to amend the Police Code to adjust various entertainment fees. The item was passed on First Reading by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent from the Board members present.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 7 SPECIAL ORDER 2:30 P.M. - Recognition of Commendations
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: A special commendation was presented to Sam Mogannam, a native San Franciscan, second-generation grocer, and visionary behind the By Rite Family of Businesses. Board President Mandelman highlighted Mogannam's family history in the city, his culinary background, the expansion of By Rite markets, his role in founding 18 Reasons (a nonprofit community cooking school), and By Rite's commitment to sustainability and equity as a B Corp. Supervisors Mahmood, Fielder, and Chan also offered praise, noting Mogannam's community collaborations, innovative non-profit grocery store model, and commitment to public safety in parks. Mogannam expressed gratitude, emphasizing the collaborative effort of his team and the public purpose of businesses to uplift communities, citing his father's lesson of feeding the hungry. The matter was then filed.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 8 COMMITTEE REPORTS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board considered two items (41 and 42) that were recommended as amended by the Rules Committee at its July 7th meeting. The amendment for both items involved striking the word 'rejecting' from their titles. Item 41, a motion to approve President Rafael Mandelman's nomination for the appointment of Gayle Starr to the Enhanced Infrastructure Financing District Public Financing Authority Number One (term ending June 6, 2029), was approved by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent. Similarly, Item 42, a motion approving President Rafael Mandelman's nomination for the appointment of Kenneth Sokoloff to the same authority (term ending June 6, 2027), was also approved by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 9 ROLL CALL FOR INTRODUCTIONS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: During the roll call for the introduction of new business, Supervisors Chan, Chen, Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Mandelman, Melgar, Sadr, Chery, and Walton submitted new items. Supervisor Sadr specifically used this opportunity to call for a public hearing on the current performance and future extension of the Central Subway. He highlighted the subway's ridership growth since its November 2022 opening, but also pointed to ongoing issues such as elevator/escalator breakdowns at the Chinatown Rose Pak Station and empty retail kiosks. Supervisor Sadr emphasized the need for specific short-term improvements from SFMTA regarding speed, reliability, and operations, and stressed the importance of planning for the extension to North Beach and Fisherman's Wharf, noting the tunnel is already dug. He underscored the need to deliver world-class transit and prepare for future federal funding opportunities, despite current transit financial challenges.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 10 PUBLIC COMMENT
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board opened a general public comment period, with the Clerk reiterating that comments on budget items (3-32) and Proposition C (Item 32) were not permitted as they had already had their public comment in committee. Speakers addressed a variety of concerns: Liam McKeever expressed confusion and frustration regarding San Francisco's sanctuary city status and SFPD's role in ICE operations. Miss Brown spoke about her murdered uncle, advocating for awareness of unsolved homicides and thanking Supervisor Dorsey for a policy on tipster payments. Jason Wyman challenged the Mayor's stated priorities, citing budget cuts to the Dream Keeper Initiative, privatization, and SFPD's militarized presence. Apple, speaking from lived experience, opposed the Mayor's 'Breaking the Cycle' initiative and reallocation of Prop C funds, advocating for voluntary care and permanent housing over forced treatment. Another speaker criticized budget decisions impacting the Black community, calling for audits and reissuance of RFPs. Christopher Klein discussed issues of 'synergy stacking of surveillance' and its impact on health. Stephanie Pinkham detailed her struggles with the non-enforcement of restraining orders against her neighbor, highlighting a public safety failure. Other speakers touched on biblical prophecy, a voluntary retirement incentive for Superior Court staff, and the divisiveness of special districts within the city.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 11 CLOSED SESSION
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board convened in a closed session to confer with or receive advice from the City Attorney regarding existing litigation. The specific litigation involved the City as a petitioner and Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) as an adverse party. Following the closed session, a motion was made by Supervisor Dorsey and seconded by Supervisor Chan, stating that the Board found it in the best interest of the public not to disclose its closed session deliberations and that no action was taken. This motion passed with a unanimous roll call vote of 11 'Aye' votes, ensuring the confidentiality of the discussions as permitted by law.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250370 Resolution to Establish - Ocean Avenue Community Benefit District
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board of Supervisors convened as a Committee of the Whole for a public hearing to consider the renewal and expansion of the Ocean Avenue Community Benefit District (CBD), also known as the Ocean Avenue Association. Item 40, a resolution to establish the CBD and order the levy and collection of assessments against properties within the district for the next 15 years (commencing FY 2025-26), was the subject. Board President Mandelman outlined the procedural aspects, including the review of the Management District Plan, Engineer's Report, and property owner ballots, noting that a majority protest (weighted ballots against exceeding those in favor) would prevent establishment. Supervisor Chan, urging support, highlighted the OAA's positive impact on the commercial corridor through murals, cleaning, community events, and small business assistance. She introduced an amendment to the Management Plan and Engineer's Report (dated July 2025) to remove 54 non-commercial parcels along Geneva Avenue, reducing the total parcels from 339 to 285 and the assessment revenue to $435,088.36, which she stated would not affect services. Supervisor Melgar also expressed strong support, emphasizing inter-district collaboration and the noticeable improvements to the corridor. Jackie Hazelwood (OEWD CBD Program Director) and Christian Martin (OAA Executive Director) presented details on the CBD's history, successful audit closure, services provided (e.g., 43,547 tasks, 62,025 lbs of trash collected), and proposed expansion to Lakeside Village. Public comment was extensive, with many property owners and community members speaking in favor, citing improved cleanliness, safety, and community vitality, while one speaker opposed, citing high assessments and vacant businesses. The amendment introduced by Supervisor Chan was moved by Supervisor Chan and seconded by Supervisor Melgar, passing without objection. After the public hearing closed, the Department of Elections tabulated the weighted ballots, reporting 70.41% in favor and 29.59% against, indicating no majority protest. Subsequently, a roll call vote was taken on Item 40, the Resolution as amended, with all 11 Supervisors voting 'Aye'. The resolution was adopted without objection, establishing the renewed and expanded Ocean Avenue Community Benefit District.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 12 FOR ADOPTION WITHOUT COMMITTEE REFERENCE
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 46 through 50 were introduced for adoption without committee reference, requiring a unanimous vote for adoption on first reading, otherwise, they would be referred to committee. Supervisor Walton requested that Items 49 and 50 be severed, and Supervisor Dorsey requested that Item 47 be severed. Initially, a roll call vote was taken on Items 46, 48, and 50, with all 11 Supervisors voting 'Aye', and these resolutions were adopted without objection. However, Supervisor Walton later requested to rescind the vote on Item 50 to allow for a 90-day extension, as groups were still working on a resolution and approaching a deadline. A motion to rescind the vote on Item 50 was made by Supervisor Chery and seconded by Supervisor Chan, passing without objection. Item 50 was then adopted (presumably for the extension) by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250728 Urging University of California Health and Blue Shield of California to Resolve Dispute Regarding Reimbursement for Medical Services and Treatment
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution urged the University of California Health and Blue Shield of California to resolve their dispute regarding reimbursement for medical services and treatment by renewing their contract, thereby preserving members' access to crucial healthcare services. Supervisor Dorsey announced that, moments before the vote, his office received word that the dispute had, in fact, been resolved, and the contract would be renewed. He thanked his colleagues, especially Supervisor Melgar and their respective staff (Mike Ferrer and Mike Bryant), for their efforts. The resolution was then approved by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent, in commemoration of the successful resolution of the dispute.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250730 Relief for Small Businesses Impacted by the Islais Creek Bridge Replacement Project
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution urged the City and County of San Francisco to establish a small business relief fund for merchants affected by the Islais Creek Bridge Replacement Project along the Third Street Corridor. Supervisor Walton highlighted that the upcoming project would shut down a significant stretch of Third Street for years, severely impacting Bayview small businesses, many of which are family-run, immigrant-owned, and Black-owned, and rely on foot traffic. She emphasized the need for the City to provide real relief, drawing parallels to past relief efforts for other major projects and during the pandemic, asserting that if the city can fund resilient infrastructure, it must also fund resilience for local economies and working-class neighborhoods. The resolution was adopted by 'Same House, Same Call', indicating unanimous consent.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 14 ADJOURNMENT
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: With no imperative agenda items or in memoriam announcements, and no further business before the Board, the meeting was adjourned.

summary_response.main_summary: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors convened its regular meeting on Tuesday, July 15, 2025. The meeting began with a roll call, land acknowledgment, and the Pledge of Allegiance, followed by communications from the Clerk regarding public participation and ADA accommodations. The Board approved past meeting minutes and then proceeded to vote on a consent agenda. A significant portion of the meeting was dedicated to the City's budget (Items 7-38), which involved extensive debate, particularly concerning the 'Our City, Our Home' fund reallocation and the 'Open for Business Act' related to procurement reform. Several budget items were severed for individual votes due to differing opinions among Supervisors. A special order of business was held at 2:30 PM to recognize and commend several individuals for their meritorious service, including a lengthy tribute to the retiring Budget and Legislative Analyst, Harvey Rose, and acknowledgments of prominent disability rights advocates. New legislation was introduced, covering topics from public safety protocols regarding federal immigration enforcement to schoolyard access and food purchasing standards. The meeting concluded with general public comment, where citizens raised concerns on various issues, and the adjournment in memory of several individuals.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 1 ROLL CALL AND PLEDGE OF ALLEGIANCE
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The meeting commenced with a roll call conducted by the Madam Clerk, confirming all Supervisors were present. President Mandelman then delivered a land acknowledgment, recognizing the unceded ancestral homeland of the Ramaytush Ohlone people. Following this, the Board members recited the Pledge of Allegiance.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 2 COMMUNICATIONS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Madam Clerk provided communications to the Board and public, outlining options for attending the meeting in person or viewing it online via SFGovTV. She informed the public that items 7 through 36, comprising the City's budget, had already undergone public comment during committee hearings and that speakers on these items would be redirected. Instructions for submitting public comment via email or postal service were provided. The Clerk also announced ADA accommodations, including American Sign Language interpreters from 2 PM to 4 PM and one remote caller, as well as simultaneous Spanish interpretation services from 2:30 PM to 6 PM, with listening devices available.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 3 APPROVAL OF MEETING MINUTES
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: President Mandelman called for the approval of the June 10, 2025, Regular Board Meeting minutes and the June 11, 12, and 13, 2025, Special Meeting minutes of the Budget and Appropriations Committee. A motion to approve the minutes as presented was made by Supervisor Walton and seconded by Supervisor Sadr. The motion passed with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes, without objection, after public comment.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 4 CONSENT AGENDA[Consent Boiler|B1]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 1 through 6 were presented as the Consent Agenda, considered routine. No objections were raised to remove any item for separate consideration. The motion to approve the Consent Agenda passed with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes, without objection, and the ordinances were finally passed.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: Items 1 through 6
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: These items were approved as part of the Consent Agenda. They included: 250589 Budget and Appropriation Ordinance for Departments - FYs 2025-2026 and 2026-2027; 250590 Annual Salary Ordinance - FYs 2025-2026 and 2026-2027; 250591 Administrative Code - City Hall Short Term License Fees; 250593 Administrative Code - Transferring Data Collection Oversight Duties from the City Administrator to the Human Rights Commission; 250594 Administrative Code - Treasure Island Development Authority; 250595 Administrative Code - Eliminating Budget Savings Incentive Fund.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250589 Budget and Appropriation Ordinance for Departments - FYs 2025-2026 and 2026-2027
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which appropriates all estimated receipts and expenditures for City and County departments as of May 30, 2025, for the fiscal years ending June 30, 2026, and June 30, 2027, was initially part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was later voted on separately as Item 7. Supervisor Chan noted that technical adjustments had been sent by the Budget Director for this item and Item 8. A motion to accept these technical adjustments for Items 7 and 8 was made by Supervisor Chan and seconded by Supervisor Walton, passing without objection. Item 7, as amended, was then voted on as part of a package with Items 16, 20, 21, and 31. The ordinance passed on first reading with a vote of 10 Ayes and 1 No (Supervisor Fielder).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250590 Annual Salary Ordinance - FYs 2025-2026 and 2026-2027
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, enumerating all positions in the annual budget and appropriation ordinance for the fiscal years ending June 30, 2026, and June 30, 2027, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). Supervisor Chan noted that technical adjustments had been sent by the Budget Director for this item and Item 7. A motion to rescind the previous vote on Item 8 was made by Supervisor Chan and seconded by Supervisor Walton, passing without objection. A subsequent motion to accept the technical adjustments for Items 7 and 8 was made by Supervisor Chan and seconded by Supervisor Walton, passing without objection. Item 8, as amended, was then voted on separately and passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250591 Administrative Code - City Hall Short Term License Fees
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Administrative Code to modify short-term license fees for the use of City Hall, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250593 Administrative Code - Transferring Data Collection Oversight Duties from the City Administrator to the Human Rights Commission
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Administrative Code to transfer responsibility for oversight of the collection of sexual orientation and gender identity data from the City Administrator to the Human Rights Commission and removes obsolete reporting requirements, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250594 Administrative Code - Treasure Island Development Authority
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Administrative Code to clarify the status of the Treasure Island Development Authority as a City department, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250595 Administrative Code - Eliminating Budget Savings Incentive Fund
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Administrative Code eliminating the Budget Savings Incentive Fund, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250596 Neighborhood Beautification and Graffiti Clean-up Fund Tax Designation Ceiling - Tax Year 2025
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which adopts the Neighborhood Beautification and Graffiti Clean-up Fund Tax Designation Ceiling for Tax Year 2025, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250597 Business and Tax Regulations Code - Early Care and Education Commercial Rents Tax Baseline - FYs 2025-2026 and 2026-2027
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which modifies the baseline funding requirements for Early Care and Education Programs in Fiscal Years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 and enables the City to use the interest earned from the Early Care and Education Commercial Rent Tax for those baseline programs, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250598 Accept and Expend Grant - Retroactive - Immigration Defense Unit - Crankstart Foundation - Amendment to the Annual Salary Ordinance for FYs 2024-2025 and 2025-2026 - $3,400,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which accepts and expends a retroactive grant for the Immigration Defense Unit from the Crankstart Foundation and amends the Annual Salary Ordinance for Fiscal Years 2024-2025 and 2025-2026 in the amount of $3.4 million, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). Supervisor Mahmood requested to sever this item for a separate vote to show unanimous support for immigration defense. Supervisor Fielder clarified that this represents philanthropic support for the Public Defender's Office, not City funding for community immigration legal defense services, which she noted was flatlined. She expressed support for the item while emphasizing the need for more comprehensive funding. The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250599 Administrative Code - Vehicle Registration Fees and Police Fingerprint Identification Fund
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Administrative Code to authorize fees for vehicles registered to a San Francisco address to fund law enforcement programs related to fingerprint identification of persons involved in crimes committed while operating motor vehicles in accordance with California State Law and establishes the Police Fingerprint Identification Fund to receive the fee revenue, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). Supervisor Fielder requested to sever this item. It was voted on as part of a package with Items 7 (as amended), 20, 21, and 31. The ordinance passed on first reading with a vote of 10 Ayes and 1 No (Supervisor Fielder).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250600 De-appropriation - San Francisco Public Utilities Commission Capital Projects Budget - $86,916 - FY2025-2026
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which de-appropriates approximately $87,000 to previously approved Ordinance Number 124-24 for the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission Capital Projects Budget and supplemental appropriation in Fiscal Year 2025-2026, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250601 San Francisco Public Utilities Commission Water Revenue Bond and Other Forms of Indebtedness Issuance - Not to Exceed $1,054,138,857
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which authorizes the issuance and sale of tax-exempt or taxable water revenue bonds for the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission Water Revenue Bond for other forms of indebtedness issuance not to exceed $1 billion, to fund various capital water and Hetch Hetchy water projects benefiting the Water Enterprise, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250602 De-appropriation - San Francisco Public Utilities Commission - $12,990,064 - FY2025-2026
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which de-appropriates approximately $13 million in the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission in Fiscal Year 2025-2026 to benefit the Water Enterprise Division from the operating budget changes driven by the Capital Improvement Projects, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250603 Park Code - Court Reservations
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Park Code to authorize the Recreation and Parks Department to charge fees for reserving tennis and pickleball courts at locations other than the Golden Gate Park Tennis Center and affirms secret determinations, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). Supervisor Fielder requested to sever this item. It was voted on as part of a package with Items 7 (as amended), 16, 21, and 31. The ordinance passed on first reading with a vote of 10 Ayes and 1 No (Supervisor Fielder).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250605 Park Code - Recreation Program Fees
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Park Code to allow the Recreation and Parks Department to set fees for recreation programs based on the department's operating costs for recreation program fees, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). Supervisor Fielder requested to sever this item. It was voted on as part of a package with Items 7 (as amended), 16, 20, and 31. The ordinance passed on first reading with a vote of 10 Ayes and 1 No (Supervisor Fielder).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250606 Various Codes - Environmental Health Permit, Fee, and Penalties Revisions
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Business and Tax Regulations Code, the Health Code, the Administrative Code, and the Public Works Code for environmental health permits, fees, and penalties revision, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250607 Health Code - Patient Rates for Fiscal Years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Health Code to set patient rates for services provided by the Department of Public Health in Fiscal Years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 and authorizes to waive or reduce fees to meet the needs of low-income patients through its provision of charity care and other discounted payment, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250608 Public Works, Subdivision Codes - Fee Modification and Waiver
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Public Works and Subdivision Codes to modify certain permit fees, including waiving fees for cafe tables and chairs and display merchandise to registrants and certain minor sidewalk encroachments that are pertinent building features, and to affirm the secret determination, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250611 Office of Community Investment and Infrastructure, Operating as Successor Agency to the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency, FY2025-2026 Budget - Issuance of Bonds - Not to Exceed $223,000,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which approves the Fiscal Year 2025-2026 budget of the Office of Community Investment and Infrastructure and approves the issuance by OCI of bonds in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed $223 million to finance a portion of OCI's enforceable obligations, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250612 Adjusting the Access Line Tax with the Consumer Price Index of 2025
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which concurs with the Controller's establishment of the Consumer Price Index for 2025 and adjusts the Access Line Tax by the same rate, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250613 Homelessness and Supportive Housing Fund - FYs 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 Expenditure Plan
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which approves the Homelessness and Supportive Housing Fund and expenditure plan for the Supportive Housing Fund, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250614 Accept and Expend Grant - Friends of San Francisco Public Library - Annual Grant Award - Up to $1,072,600 of In-Kind Gifts, Services, and Cash Monies - FY2025-2026
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which authorizes the San Francisco Public Library to accept and expend a $1 million grant of in-kind services, gifts, and cash monies from the Friends of the San Francisco Public Library for direct support of a variety of public programs, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250615 Proposition J Contract Certification Contracted-Out Department Services Previously Approved
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which concurs with the Comptroller's certification that department services previously approved can be performed by private contractor for a lower cost than similar work performed by City employees, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250616 Accept and Expend Bequest - Estate of William Benjamin Bobo - Benches, Park Furnishings and Park Improvements Across San Francisco - $3,600,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which authorizes the Recreation and Parks Department to accept and expend a $3.6 million bequest from the Estate of William Benjamin Bobo to provide benches, park furnishings, and park improvements at various park sites across San Francisco, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). Supervisor Fielder requested to sever this item. It was voted on as part of a package with Items 7 (as amended), 16, 20, and 21. The resolution was adopted with a vote of 10 Ayes and 1 No (Supervisor Fielder).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250617 Authorizing Paid Parking in Golden Gate Park
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which authorizes the Municipal Transportation Agency to set parking rates in Golden Gate Park in accordance with the Park Code provisions that authorize SFMTA rate setting on park property and affirms the secret determination, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). Supervisor Fielder requested to sever this item. It was voted on as part of a package with Items 7 (as amended), 16, 20, and 21. The resolution was adopted with a vote of 10 Ayes and 1 No (Supervisor Fielder).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250618 Accept and Expend Grants - Recurring State Grant Funds - Department of Public Health - FY2025-2026
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which authorizes the Department of Public Health to accept and expend recurring state grant funds for Fiscal Year 2025-2026, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250619 Grant Agreement - California Department of Social Services - Community Care Expansion Program - Anticipated Revenue to the City $9,895,834
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which authorizes a grant agreement for a term commencing on execution of the grant agreement through June 30, 2029, with the California Department of Social Services and a third-party administrator Horn LLP for approximately $9.9 million to construct a substance use disorder residential stepdown facility at Parcel E 1.2 Treasure Island, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250620 Accept and Expend Grant - Delegation of 9.118 Authority - Retroactive - SFHP - Housing and Homelessness Incentive Program ("HHIP") Expanding San Francisco Department of Public Health Recuperative Care Community Supports - $2,489,698.63
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which retroactively authorizes Public Health to accept and expend $2.5 million in grant funds from the California Department of Health Care Services through the San Francisco Health Authority to participate in a program entitled Housing and Homelessness Incentive Program to expand San Francisco's Department of Public Health Recuperative Care Community Support for a term of one year and one month and 16 days through June 30, 2026, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250621 Accept and Expend Grant - Delegation of Charter, Section 9.118 Authority - San Francisco Health Authority d.b.a. the San Francisco Health Plan - Incentive Payment Program - Department of Public Health Epic Enhancement Implementation Project - $6,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution, which authorizes the Department of Public Health to expend $6 million from the California Department of Health Care Services through the San Francisco Health Plan to participate in a program entitled Incentive Payment Program for Department of Public Health Epic Enhancement Implementation Project for one year from July 1, 2025, through June 30, 2026, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250609 Funding Reallocation - Our City, Our Home Homelessness Gross Receipts Tax - Services to Address Homelessness - $34,777,000 Plus Up to $19,100,000 of Future Revenue - Through FY 2026-2027
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which authorizes the City to reallocate approximately $34.7 million in prior appropriated revenue and unappropriated earned interest within the Our City Our Home (Prop C) Fund to allow the City to use revenues from the Homelessness Gross Receipts Tax through Fiscal Year 2026-2027 for certain types of services to address homelessness, was referred without recommendation from the Budget and Appropriations Committee. Supervisor Fielder expressed deep concern about Section 4, which would eliminate the supermajority requirement for approving future surplus funds, calling it a dangerous precedent and an attack on local democracy. She requested to divide the question to vote separately on Section 4. Supervisor Walton supported Fielder's concerns, stating that waiving the supermajority threshold undermines voter will and legislative authority. Supervisor Chan, the Budget Committee Chair, explained that the legislation evolved from an initial proposal to reallocate $88 million and now includes a cap of $19 million for simple majority reallocation, limited to the end of FY 2026-2027, with any additional changes still requiring a supermajority. President Mandelman supported both parts, arguing that the original Prop C allocations were debatable and that the current provision allows for rationalized spending. The Clerk clarified that an 8-vote threshold (supermajority) was required for the ordinance. The Board first voted on Section 4 of Item 36, which passed on first reading with 8 Ayes and 3 Noes (Supervisors Chin, Fielder, and Walton). The remainder of Item 36 then passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250592 Building, Subdivision, and Administrative Codes - Fee Adjustment and Building Inspection Fund Subfunds
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Building, Subdivision, and Administrative Codes to adjust fees charged by the Department of Building Inspection and to establish subfunds within the Building Inspection Fund and affirm the secret determination, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250604 Park Code - Cost Recovery for Use of Golf Courses, Outdoor Event Facilities, Picnic Areas, and Athletic Fields; Golf Course Fees Generally
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Park Code for cost recovery for use of golf courses, outdoor event facilities, picnic areas, and athletic fields, and golf course fees generally, was part of the larger budget discussion (Items 7-38). It was voted on as part of the main budget package (Items 8-14, 17-19, 22-30, 32-35, 37-38, excluding 7, 15, 16, 20, 21, 31). The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 7 SPECIAL ORDER 2:30 P.M. - Recognition of Commendations
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board held a special order of business to recognize individuals for meritorious service. This included a commendation for Harvey Rose, the retiring Budget and Legislative Analyst, for over five decades of service, featuring a video tribute and speeches from Supervisors Walton, Melgar, Chan, and former Board members Judge Quentin Kopp and Aaron Peskin. Other commendations were presented to the Göttingen Neighbors Group for their 'Steps to Wisdom' project, Patty Carmen for her retirement from Catholic Charities, Commander Eric Kim for his service as Central Station Captain, Lucas Kelly and Max Banks for their selection in the MLB Draft, Alice Wong for her leadership in the disability justice movement, Sasha Bittner for her advocacy in disability rights and domestic workers' rights, and Debbie Kaplan for her pioneering work as a disability rights attorney and activist. Many of the honorees and their representatives spoke, often highlighting the importance of community, advocacy, and addressing systemic issues.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250192 Administrative, Labor and Employment Codes - City Contract Processes and Requirements
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, known as the 'Open for Business Act,' aims to update City processes and requirements related to contracting. President Mandelman introduced the item, explaining it seeks to streamline procurement, especially for low-dollar contracts, by cleaning up outdated laws, streamlining duplicative processes, and requiring more rigorous review for future procurement legislation. He also proposed an amendment to address the City Administrator's analysis timeframe for future legislation. Supervisor Walton moved to send the item back to committee to remove the elimination of the Sweatshop Committee, seconded by Supervisor Melgar. Supervisor Chan supported sending it back, reading a statement from Tim Paulson and Tom Ammiano opposing weakening sweat-free labor standards. Supervisor Mahmood opposed sending it back, arguing for the necessity of streamlining. Supervisor Engardio supported sending it back to discuss the sensitive issue of the Sweatshop Advisory Committee. Supervisor Dorsey supported moving forward, criticizing the City's inefficient contracting processes. Supervisor Fielder also supported sending it back, viewing the proposed changes as a 'wholesale retreat' from protecting workers' rights. President Mandelman strongly opposed sending it back, arguing that the Sweatshop Advisory Committee is ineffective and that the legislation preserves sweat-free principles while making modest, necessary tweaks for efficiency. The motion to accept President Mandelman's amendment passed without objection. The subsequent motion to send Item 39 to committee (as amended) passed with a vote of 6 Ayes and 5 Noes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250655 Various Codes - Large and Commercial Vehicle Parking Restrictions - Hours and Exceptions
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance amends various codes to update parking restrictions for large commercial vehicles, including amending hours and exceptions, and to affirm the second determination. Supervisor Melgar provided context, explaining the legislation's aim to address issues with recreational vehicles (RVs) and large commercial vehicles parked on city streets. She highlighted the creation of a 'refuge permit system' for RV dwellers, a buyback program for vehicles, and the restriction of large commercial vehicles to improve public safety and manage public right-of-way. Supervisor Chan supported the legislation, acknowledging concerns but emphasizing the compassionate solutions and exemptions provided, and committed to requesting regular reports on its implementation. Supervisor Walton strongly opposed the legislation, arguing it is 'operationally impossible' to implement, will 'criminalize people,' and is an 'attack on people trying to have a shelter,' as it does not provide sufficient housing alternatives. The ordinance passed on first reading with a vote of 9 Ayes and 2 Noes (Supervisors Fielder and Walton).

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250677 Sale of General Obligation Bonds (Health and Recovery, 2020), Series 2025G, - Not to Exceed $150,000,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution authorizes the issuance and sale of up to $150 million in aggregate principal amounts of one or more series of bonds on a tax-exempt or taxable basis of City GO Bonds for Health and Recovery. It also approves the forms of official notice of sale, notice of intention to sell, and directing the publication of the notice, the purchase contract, the preliminary official statement, and the execution of the official statement of such bonds, including the continuing disclosure certificate. This item was voted on as part of a package with Items 42 and 43. The resolution was adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250678 Appropriation - General Obligation Bond Proceeds - $150,000,000 - 2020 Health and Recovery, Series 2025G - DPH, MOHCD - FY2025-2026
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance appropriates $150 million of the General Obligation (GO) Bond proceeds from 2020 Health and Recovery GO Bonds Series 2025G to the Department of Public Health and the Mayor's Office of Housing and Community Development for acquisition and improvement of real property for various behavioral and mental health facilities or for permanent supportive housing or shelters and related costs in Fiscal Year 2025-2026, and to place the funds on Controller's Reserve pending receipt of the bond proceeds. This item was voted on as part of a package with Items 41 and 43. The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250679 De-Appropriation - General Obligation Bond Proceeds - $160,467,200 - 2020 Health and Recovery, Series 2021D - DPH, HOM - FY2025-2026
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance de-appropriates approximately $160.5 million of General Obligation Bond proceeds from 2020 Health and Recovery G.O. Bond Series 2021D from the Department of Public Health and the Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing in Fiscal Year 2025-2026. This item was voted on as part of a package with Items 41 and 42. The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250380 Accept and Expend Grant - Retroactive - Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration - Naloxone Distribution Project - Valued at $14,400
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution retroactively authorizes the Police Department to accept and expend an in-kind gift of 600 units of Naloxone valued at approximately $14,400 through the Naloxone Distribution Project, funded by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration and administered by the Department of Health Care Services, for a grant term of August 7, 2024, through December 31, 2024. The resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250511 Contract - Seneca Family of Agencies - FCS Wraparound Services - Not to Exceed $15,974,640
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution approves an agreement between the City and Seneca Family of Agencies for the provision of Family and Children's Services Wraparound Services for a term of four years (July 1, 2025, through June 30, 2029) and for a total amount of $15.9 million. It also authorizes the Executive Director of the Human Services Agency to make necessary non-material changes to the agreement before execution. The resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250577 Professional Services Agreement - CDM Smith, Inc. - Professional Services for Sunol Valley Facilities Improvements - Not to Exceed $15,000,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution approves and authorizes the General Manager of the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission to execute a contract for professional services for Central Valley Facilities Improvements with CDM Smith Inc. for a contract amount of $15 million and a contract duration of ten years (through July 2035). The services include planning and engineering design and support necessary for the design and construction of improvements to various San Francisco Public Utilities Commission facilities in Sunol Valley, pursuant to Charter Section 9.118. The resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250578 Agreement Amendment - Arcadis U.S. Inc - Biosolids Digester Facilities Construction Management Staff Augmentation Services - Not to Exceed $68,500,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution approves and authorizes the General Manager of the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission to execute the first amendment to a contract for Biosolids Digester Facilities Construction Management Staff Augmentation Services with Arcadis U.S. Inc. The amendment increases the contract amount by $26.5 million for a new total of $68.5 million and increases the contract duration by three years and nine months (now through May 27, 2029) to reflect the current schedule and budget for the Digester Facilities Project and to ensure continued qualified experienced construction management, pursuant to Charter Section 9.118. The resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250581 Grant Agreement - Meals on Wheels San Francisco - Home-Delivered Meal Nutrition Services to Older Adults - Not to Exceed $37,127,237
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution approves a grant agreement between the City, acting through the Department of Disability and Aging Services, and Meals on Wheels San Francisco for the provision of home-delivered meal nutrition services for older adults for a four-year term (July 1, 2025, through June 30, 2029) and a not-to-exceed amount of $37.1 million. The resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250637 Accept and Expend Loan - Bay Area Housing Finance Authority - Priority Sites Pilot Program Fund Infrastructure Improvements Serving the Treasure Island Affordable Senior Housing Project - $3,000,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution authorizes the Treasure Island Director of Treasure Island Development Authority to execute an affordable housing loan agreement with the Bay Area Housing Finance Authority under the Regional Early Action Planning Grant 2.0 Priority Sites Pilot Program for a total award of $3 million, disbursed as an unsecured low-interest loan to the Authority to fund design, permitting, or construction of infrastructure improvements serving the affordable housing Parcel E 1.2 Senior Housing Project on Treasure Island. The loan has a three-year term from the execution date of the agreement with the option of two one-year extensions. It also authorizes the Authority to accept and expend the funds for eligible costs approved by the BHFA and to execute and deliver documents, including a memorandum of agreement with the Treasure Island Community Development. The resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250638 Accept and Expend Grant - Retroactive - The Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development - Cannabis Equity Grants Program for Local Jurisdictions - $3,324,052.50
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution retroactively authorizes the Office of Cannabis to accept and expend an approximate $3.3 million grant award and to expend interest earned or accrued on grant funds for the grant term through October 31, 2026, from the Governor's Office of Business and Economic Development for the Local Equity Grants Program for Local Jurisdictions. The resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250658 Apply for, Accept and Expend Grant - Retroactive - San Francisco Bay Area Water Emergency Transportation Authority - Mission Bay Ferry Landing - $28,000,000
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution retroactively authorizes the Port of San Francisco to accept and expend a $28 million grant from the San Francisco Bay Area Water Emergency Transportation Authority to fund the Mission Bay Ferry Landing Project through October 1, 2028. The resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250508 Administrative Code - Contracting Minimum Competitive Amount and Threshold Amount
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance amends the Administrative Code to update the minimum competitive amount and threshold amount for contracting to reflect recent Consumer Price Index increases, to update the local business enterprise size criteria amounts to reflect recent Consumer Price Index increases, to align the Consumer Price Index increases with the fiscal year, and to add delegated purchasing amount as a defined term in the Administrative Code. The ordinance was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 8 COMMITTEE REPORTS [Committee Report Boiler|B1, B2]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board considered a committee report from the Land Use and Transportation Committee.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250542 Planning Code - Fenestration, Transparency, and Sign Requirements Generally; Sales and Service Uses in the C-3 and RC Districts
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This ordinance, which amends the Planning Code to finish duration, transparency, and sign requirements generally for sales and service uses in the C-3 and RC Districts, and to affirm the second determination and to make the appropriate findings, was considered by the Land Use and Transportation Committee on Monday, July 14th, and recommended as a committee report. The ordinance passed on first reading with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 9 ROLL CALL FOR INTRODUCTIONS [Roll Call Boiler|B1, B2]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Supervisors introduced new business items. Supervisor Chen introduced a resolution affirming due process rights and community partnership for public safety, urging law enforcement training regarding federal immigration enforcement, and a draft request for the City Attorney to codify a 'Good Neighborhood Policy' for covered facilities. Supervisor Dorsey introduced a resolution reaffirming support for the San Francisco School District's Shared Schoolyards Program. Supervisor Fielder submitted a formal letter of inquiry to the Police Department, Sheriff's Department, and Comptroller regarding police leadership remarks on protecting ICE agents, data sharing practices, and costs of protest deployment, and an In Memoriam for Jesus Ramos, Joni Ernst Ramos, and Joel Jeremiah Melendez. Supervisor Mahmood introduced a letter of inquiry to SFPD Interim Chief Yap regarding captain turnover. President Mandelman introduced a resolution recognizing the 35th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act and celebrating disability rights leaders in San Francisco. Supervisor Melgar submitted her items and asked to be added to Supervisor Fielder's In Memoriam. Supervisor Sadr introduced a resolution authorizing the Little Italy Honor Walk. Supervisor Cheryl submitted her items. Supervisor Walton introduced an ordinance to make the City's Good Food Purchasing Standards permanent for hospitals and jails, and an In Memoriam for Priscilla Breed, mother of Mayor London Breed. Supervisor Chan offered an In Memoriam for Mrs. Renata Margaret Kennison.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 10 PUBLIC COMMENT [Public Comment Boiler|B1, B2, N1]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Public comment was opened for items 57 through 60 and other general matters, with budget items and other agenda items already dealt with being excluded. A remote caller, Patricia Eric, a member of the Mayor's Disability Council, spoke about safety concerns for pedestrians and bikers at Sunset Dunes. In-chamber speakers included an individual who mentioned Bastille Day and alleged a pedophile ring in government, Michael Frazier who spoke about missing children and the sex slave industry, Liam McKeever who protested ICE actions and read a poem, Mr. Armond who spoke about the situation in Palestine, Mark Bruno from St. Vincent de Paul Society who opposed upzoning that demolishes affordable units, and Ms. Bro who pleaded for the Board's support at an upcoming anniversary of her son's death due to senseless violence.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 12 FOR ADOPTION WITHOUT COMMITTEE REFERENCE[For Adoption Boiler|B1,B2]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 57 through 60 were introduced for adoption without committee reference, requiring a unanimous vote for adoption of a resolution on first reading, or a member could require it to go to committee. Supervisor Chan requested to sever and continue Items 59 and 60 for one week to allow her to vote 'No' on principle, consistent with her previous vote on the subject projects. A motion to continue these two items was made by Supervisor Chan and seconded by Supervisor Melgar, passing without objection. Items 57 and 58 were then voted on together and adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: Items 57 through 60
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: These items were introduced for adoption without committee reference. Items 57 and 58 were adopted with a unanimous vote of 11 Ayes. Items 59 and 60 were severed and continued for one week at the request of Supervisor Chan to allow her to vote 'No' on principle, consistent with her previous vote on the subject projects. The motion to continue passed without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250746 Adoption of Findings Related to Conditional Use Authorization - 3400 Laguna Street
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was a motion to adopt findings related to a conditional use authorization at 3400 Laguna Street. It was severed from the package of items for adoption without committee reference and continued for one week at the request of Supervisor Chan, seconded by Supervisor Melgar, to allow Supervisor Chan to vote 'No' on principle, consistent with her previous vote on the subject project. The motion to continue passed without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250747 Adoption of Findings Related to Certificate of Appropriateness - 3400 Laguna Street
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was a motion to adopt findings and support of the certificate of appropriateness at 3400 Laguna Street. It was severed from the package of items for adoption without committee reference and continued for one week at the request of Supervisor Chan, seconded by Supervisor Melgar, to allow Supervisor Chan to vote 'No' on principle, consistent with her previous vote on the subject project. The motion to continue passed without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 14 ADJOURNMENT
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The meeting concluded after all agenda items were addressed. The Clerk read the In Memoriam for several beloved individuals: Jesus Ramos, Gianni Ramos, Joel Jeremiah Melendez (on behalf of Supervisors Fielder and Melgar); Mrs. Renata Marguerite Kennison (on behalf of Supervisor Chan); and Ms. Priscilla Breed (on behalf of Supervisor Walton and President Mandelman, and the entire Board of Supervisors). With no further business, the meeting was adjourned.

summary_response.main_summary:
The San Francisco Board of Supervisors convened its regular meeting on Tuesday, July 22, 2025. The meeting began with a roll call, confirming all members were present, followed by a land acknowledgment and the Pledge of Allegiance. The Clerk provided communications regarding public access to meetings and public comment procedures, notably restricting comments on budget items (5-25) and Item 26. The Board then approved past meeting minutes and passed consent agenda items (1-4) unanimously.

Unfinished business included the final reading of the City's budget (Items 5-24), which was voted on in two batches. Item 25, concerning the Homelessness Gross Receipts Tax reallocation, required a supermajority vote and was handled as a divided question, with both parts passing. Item 26, regarding large and commercial vehicle parking restrictions, also passed. Several other ordinances and resolutions were passed on first reading or adopted, often by unanimous consent ('Same House, Same Call'), including amendments to the Administrative Code for procurement (Item 27), real property acquisition (Item 28), and health service system rates (Item 29, requiring a three-fourths vote).

A significant portion of the meeting was dedicated to Special Orders. At 2:30 p.m., commendations were given to Commander Luke Martin of the SFPD, Jolene's Bar and its owner Jolene, the first class of women police officers from the 126th Recruit Class (1975), Central Drugstore and Jerry Tonelli, Darlene Armenino of SFERS, and Mohammad Yasir of DPW. At 3:00 p.m., the Board convened as a Committee of the Whole for a public hearing on the renewal and expansion of the Dogpatch and Northwest Potrero Hill Green Benefit District (Items 47 and 48). Presentations were made by Public Works and the GBD, followed by public comments largely in support. After ballot tabulation showed no majority protest, Item 48 was adopted unanimously.

Following the special orders, the Board debated Item 42, a resolution to oppose California State Senate Bill No. 79 (Wiener) unless amended, concerning transit-oriented development. After a robust discussion among supervisors, the resolution was not adopted, failing to gain majority support. Subsequent committee reports, including numerous lawsuit settlements (Items 49-63), were passed on first reading. New business was introduced by various supervisors, covering topics such as landmarking the Mint Mall, addressing low traffic enforcement, supporting the Golden State Valkyries for equal pay, designating Pete Escovedo Day, declaring South Asian American Heritage Month, investigating conditions at the 111 Taylor reentry facility, establishing a small business relief fund, and creating a 'Workers Opportunity to Purchase Act.'

General public comment followed, with speakers addressing a range of issues including the 111 Taylor facility and the death of Melvin Balogun, the South Asian American Heritage Month resolution, and other city matters. Finally, the Board considered items for adoption without committee reference, pulling some for individual votes. Items 70 and 71, related to findings for a project at 3400 Laguna Street, were approved with an eight-vote threshold. Item 74, declaring August 2025 as Afghan-American Heritage Month, was adopted unanimously. The meeting concluded with adjournments in memory of Dan Dillon, Christopher Charles Brunetti, Maureen Dowling, and Melvin Balogun.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 1 ROLL CALL AND PLEDGE OF ALLEGIANCE
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The meeting commenced with a roll call conducted by the Madam Clerk, confirming the presence of all eleven members of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors: Supervisor Chan, Supervisor Chen, Supervisor Dorsey, Supervisor Engardio, Supervisor Fielder, Supervisor Mahmood, Supervisor Randleman, Supervisor Melgar, Supervisor Sadr, Supervisor Cheryl, and Supervisor Walton. Following the roll call, the President acknowledged that the Board was meeting on the unceded ancestral homeland of the Ramaytush Ohlone people. The Board then recited the Pledge of Allegiance. The President also acknowledged the staff of SFGovTV for recording meetings and making transcripts available online.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 2 COMMUNICATIONS
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Madam Clerk provided communications to the public regarding meeting attendance and participation. She informed attendees that the meeting was held in Room 250 of City Hall and could be watched on SFGovTV Channel 26 or live-streamed online. Public comment could be submitted via email to boss@sf.gov.org or by postal service to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, City Hall, Room 244, San Francisco, California 94102. A critical procedural note was made: public comment time for Items 5 through 25 (the City's budget) and Item 26 (Large and Commercial Vehicle Parking Restrictions) had closed, and speakers attempting to comment on these items during general public comment would be redirected. Requests for reasonable accommodation under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) or language assistance were to be directed to the Clerk's office at least two business days in advance.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 3 APPROVAL OF MEETING MINUTES
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The Board considered the approval of the June 17, 2025, Regular Board Meeting Minutes and the June 18, 20, and 23, 2025, Special Meeting Minutes of the Budget and Appropriations Committee, which constituted a quorum of the Board of Supervisors. A motion to approve the minutes as presented was made by Supervisor Cheryl and seconded by Supervisor Chan. Upon a roll call vote, all eleven Supervisors (Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Walton, Chan, and Chen) voted 'Aye'. The minutes were approved with 11 Ayes and 0 Noes, without objection, to be formally approved after public comment.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 4 CONSENT AGENDA[Consent Boiler|B1]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: Items 1 through 4 were placed on the Consent Agenda, which are considered routine and can be removed for separate consideration if a member objects. No objections were raised, and no members were on the roster to speak. The Madam Clerk called the roll on Items 1 through 4. All eleven Supervisors (Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Walton, Chan, and Chen) voted 'Aye'. With 11 Ayes and 0 Noes, the ordinances were finally passed without objection.
