agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 7 SPECIAL ORDER 2:30 P.M. - Recognition of Commendations
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
The Board proceeded to its 2:30 p.m. Special Order for the recognition of meritorious service. Supervisor Dorsey recognized Commander Luke Martin of the San Francisco Police Department for his leadership at Southern Station, professionalism, integrity, and commitment to community engagement and public safety, particularly during challenging times in District Six. Michelle Delaney from the Community Police Advisory Board also spoke in support of Commander Martin's promotion. Commander Martin expressed gratitude for the support from the Board, his colleagues, and his family.

Supervisor Fielder recognized Jolene's Bar and its owner Jolene, located in the Mission District, as a sanctuary and vital part of San Francisco's LGBTQ+ community, women, and people of color, highlighting its role in activism and community building. Jolene thanked her staff and the community for their support.

Supervisor Walton honored the first class of women police officers from the 126th Recruit Class, sworn in on July 28, 1975, as the first women assigned to full patrol duties in the SFPD. Arlene George, a member of the class, provided a brief history of their journey, acknowledging the Officers for Justice lawsuit and the challenges they faced. She thanked her family, the police department, and her classmates.

Supervisor Chen honored Central Drugstore, a legacy business in the Excelsior District, for over a century of compassion, care, and community service, highlighting its role as a pharmacy and general store, and its support for local organizations. Jerry Tonelli, whose family ran the store for generations, expressed gratitude for the recognition upon its closing.

Supervisor Cheryl commended Darlene Armenino on her retirement after an extraordinary 50-year career in San Francisco's legal and public service sectors, including her significant role at the San Francisco Employees Retirement System (SFERS). Darlene expressed her gratitude for the unexpected recognition.

Supervisor Mahmood recognized Mohammad Yasir, a public servant with DPW, a labor leader, community organizer, father, and caregiver, for his deep commitment to the city, particularly in addressing the fentanyl crisis. Supervisors Chen, Fielder, and Walton also spoke in support of Yasir, highlighting his work with SEIU 2015, the Council on American-Islamic Relations, and his dedication to social justice. Yasir expressed his honor and commitment to continue serving vulnerable and marginalized communities.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250470 Hearing - Committee of the Whole - Dogpatch and Northwest Potrero Hill Green Benefit District - Renewal and Expansion - July 22, 2025, at 3:00 p.m.
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
The Board convened as a Committee of the Whole for a public hearing to establish, renew, and expand the Property Based Business Improvement District known as the Dogpatch and Northwest Potrero Hill Green Benefit District (GBD), pursuant to a resolution adopted on May 20, 2025. The purpose was to hear testimony on the renewal and expansion. The Department of Elections would count all ballots submitted, including any additional ballots received during the hearing, and submit the tabulation later in the meeting. A majority protest (weighted ballots in opposition exceeding those in favor) would prevent approval. Supervisor Walton spoke in support, highlighting the GBD as the only Green Benefits District in San Francisco, a model for greener, cleaner, and more livable neighborhoods, and its role in supporting climate goals and building community.

Esther Lee, Government Affairs Liaison with San Francisco Public Works, and James Cassel, Public Works Committee Programs Support Specialist, presented, joined by Shawn Trotman, Board President of the Dogpatch and Northwest Potrero Hill Green Benefit District. Ms. Lee thanked Supervisor Walton and City employees for their support. Mr. Trotman presented on the GBD's impact, noting that it has more than tripled public green space from two to seven acres in ten years, raising $21 million through assessments and additional donations. He detailed community engagement through volunteer events and music series, maintenance efforts (including distributing over 58,000 doggie bags), litter removal, and graffiti abatement. He explained the proposed slight expansion of boundaries for the next 15-year term (through 2040) and the GBD's robust project pipeline. He highlighted the GBD's success in transforming land adjacent to freeways into usable parks.

Public comment was opened for this specific hearing. Speakers Catherine Domine, Susan Hasluck, Richard Romero, and Rebecca Groves, all residents of Dogpatch, spoke in strong support, praising the GBD's positive impact on community, green spaces, and quality of life. J.R. Hepler, President of the Potrero Boosters Neighborhood Association, also spoke in support, emphasizing the GBD's role in addressing post-industrial blight and maintaining improvements. One speaker made unrelated comments. The public comment period was then closed, and the hearing was filed, pending ballot tabulation.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250471 Establish, Renew and Expand - Dogpatch and Northwest Potrero Hill Green Benefit District
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was considered after the Committee of the Whole hearing and the tabulation of ballots by the Department of Elections. The Madam Clerk announced the election results: 60.91% of returned weighted ballots voted 'For' the Dogpatch and Northwest Potrero Hill Green Benefit District, and 39.09% voted 'Against'. This indicated that there was no majority protest. Upon a roll call vote, all eleven Supervisors (Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Walton, Chan, and Chen) voted 'Aye'. With 11 Ayes and 0 Noes, the resolution was adopted, establishing, renewing, and expanding the district.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250727 Opposing California State Senate Bill No. 79 (Wiener) Unless Amended - Housing Development: Transit-Oriented Development
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution was referred without recommendation from the Land Use and Transportation Committee. Supervisor Chan introduced the resolution, stating it was not to oppose SB 79 entirely but as it is currently written, particularly regarding the demolition of rent-controlled units. She shared a personal story about the importance of rent-controlled housing for her family and expressed concern that SB 79, without amendments, would allow demolition without adequate local control or tenant/small business protection, setting a 'floor' for upzoning. Supervisor Melgar stated she was not ready to support opposing SB 79, citing ongoing work with Assembly Member Haney and Senator Wiener on amendments, and emphasizing the bill's positive direction for transit-oriented development in California. Supervisor Mahmood spoke in support of SB 79, highlighting its allowance for building homes near transit, support for transit systems, and existing strong demolition restrictions and local tenant/affordability protections. Supervisor Dorsey also supported SB 79, arguing it addresses housing, transit, and climate goals, and that recent amendments balance these needs. Supervisor Chen, a co-sponsor of the opposition resolution, emphasized the need for tailored policies, anti-displacement strategies, and protection for rent-controlled housing. Supervisor Cheryl reiterated that SB 79 has strong anti-demolition protections and allows for local exemptions, advocating for a regional approach to affordability. Upon a roll call vote, Supervisors Fielder, Walton, Chan, and Chen voted 'Aye' (in favor of opposing the bill), while Supervisors Dorsey, Engardio, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, and Cheryl voted 'No' (against opposing the bill). With 4 Ayes and 7 Noes, the resolution was not adopted.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250284 Planning, Building Codes - Noncomplying, Unpermitted, and Accessory Structures
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was considered by the Land Use and Transportation Committee on Monday, July 21, and was recommended as a Committee Report. The Madam Clerk read the full title of Item 64, an ordinance to amend the Planning Code to provide conditions for repair and relocation of existing non-complying structures within required yards, grant unpermitted residential structures within yards that were constructed before 2003 non-complying status, and to allow accessory structures up to ten feet in height and 120 square feet within required yards, to amend the Building Code to exempt accessory structures up to 120 square feet from building permits, and to affirm the CEQA (California Environmental Quality Act) determination and to make the appropriate findings. The Board proceeded with a 'Same House, Same Call' vote (unanimous consent). Without objection, the ordinance was passed on first reading.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250681 Administrative Code - Employee Donations to San Francisco Firefighter and EMS Behavioral Health Foundation
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item, along with Items 66 and 67, was considered by the Rules Committee on Monday, July 21, and was recommended as a Committee Report. The Madam Clerk read the full title of Item 65, an ordinance to amend the Administrative Code to add the San Francisco Firefighter and EMS Behavioral Health Foundation to the list of organizations to which City officers and employees may make donations by payroll deduction. The Board proceeded with a 'Same House, Same Call' vote (unanimous consent). Without objection, the ordinance was passed on first reading.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250699 Administrative Code - Real Time Investigation Center - Waiving Solicitation Requirements For Procurements Using Gift Funds From San Francisco Police Community Foundation
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was considered by the Rules Committee on Monday, July 21, and was recommended as a Committee Report bearing a new title. The Madam Clerk read the new title of Item 66: 'Ordinance waiving the competitive solicitation requirements under Chapter 21 of the Administrative Code for the Police Department's procurement of equipment, technology, and services to support the Department's Real Time Investigation Center using gift funds received from the San Francisco Police Community Foundation.' Upon a roll call vote, Supervisors Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Chan, and Chen voted 'Aye', while Supervisor Walton voted 'No'. With 10 Ayes and 1 No, the ordinance was passed on first reading.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250715 Administrative Code - Regional Vehicle Interdiction Desk Grant Program - Waiving Competitive Solicitation Requirements for Procurements Using Grant Funds
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was considered by the Rules Committee on Monday, July 21, and was recommended as a Committee Report also with a new title. The Madam Clerk read the new title of Item 67: 'Ordinance waiving the competitive solicitation requirements under Chapter 21 of the Administrative Code for the Police Department's procurement of equipment, technology, and services for the Regional Vehicle Interdiction Desk using grant funds from the United States Department of Justice, Bureau of Justice Assistance.' Upon a roll call vote, Supervisors Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Chan, and Chen voted 'Aye', while Supervisor Walton voted 'No'. With 10 Ayes and 1 No, the ordinance was passed on first reading.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 9 ROLL CALL FOR INTRODUCTIONS [Roll Call Boiler|B1, B2]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
Supervisors introduced new business:

*   **Supervisor Dorsey** introduced a resolution to initiate the landmarking process for the Mint Mall, an invaluable neighborhood asset for the SoMa and Filipino communities, noting it would be the first landmark report written bilingually in English and Filipino. He also requested adjourning the meeting in memory of Dan Dillon, a beloved San Franciscan and civic leader.
*   **Supervisor Engardio** requested a hearing to learn more about the root cause of low levels of traffic enforcement across the city, citing a 95% drop in citations and high traffic fatalities. He also introduced a resolution urging the City Services Auditor to work with San Francisco Public Works to develop objective and measurable standards for streetscape projects, open spaces, and planted medians.
*   **Supervisor Fielder** introduced a resolution in support of the Golden State Valkyries (WNBA team) and their efforts for a fair collective bargaining agreement and equal compensation for WNBA athletes, highlighting the disparity in pay compared to NBA counterparts. He also introduced a resolution to designate August 2, 2025, as Pete Escovedo Day, honoring the legendary Bay Area percussionist and visual artist.
*   **Supervisor Mahmood** introduced a resolution declaring July 18th to August 17th as South Asian American Heritage Month, recognizing the vibrant and growing South Asian community's contributions to the city. He also requested a hearing to investigate the conditions of the reentry facility at 111 Taylor and the ongoing role of its operator, GEO Group, following the death of Melvin Balogun, and requested adjourning the meeting in Mr. Balogun's memory.
*   **Supervisor Melgar** honored the life of Maureen Dowling, a remarkable San Franciscan and Irish immigrant. She introduced the first part of a rezoning response and readiness package, including an expansion of options under the inclusionary ordinance for well-resourced neighborhoods (allowing developers to include below-market-rate units, pay a fee, or dedicate land, and an option for all units to be subject to rent control). She also introduced a resolution to express interest in forming an Enhanced Infrastructure Finance District for affordable housing creation in well-resourced neighborhoods, and legislation to establish a Small Business Rezoning Construction Relief Fund and Program.
*   **Supervisor Sadr** submitted his introductions.
*   **Supervisor Cheryl** submitted her introductions.
*   **Supervisor Walton** submitted her introductions.
*   **Supervisor Chan** introduced two pieces of legislation: an ordinance to extend existing interim zoning control into a permanent ordinance, requiring conditional use authorization whenever a new business attempts to displace a legacy business or neighborhood anchoring business; and the 'Workers Opportunity to Purchase Act' to create a pathway for existing workers to purchase a business as a cooperative when the owner intends to sell.
*   **Supervisor Chen** submitted his introductions.
*   **President Randleman** introduced a resolution recognizing July 22, 2025, as Lady Gaga Day, as she was performing at Chase Center. He also introduced a resolution to recognize August 4th through August 8th, 2025, as National Health Center Week in San Francisco, acknowledging the San Francisco Community Clinic Consortium. Lastly, he requested adjourning the meeting in memory of Christopher Charles Brunetti.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 10 PUBLIC COMMENT [Public Comment Boiler|B1, B2, N1]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
The Board opened general public comment. The Madam Clerk reiterated that comments on budget items (5-25) and Item 26 (Large and Commercial Vehicle Parking Restrictions) were not permitted. Each speaker was allotted two minutes.

Speakers addressed various topics:
*   One speaker made unrelated comments about 'pedophiles in control of the government' and a 'book revolution'.
*   Jeffrey Almond demanded a full Board vote on a ceasefire in Israel/Palestine, threatening the President's position if not met.
*   Dakota Rose, co-founder of Trans Visible and a reentry advocate, spoke about atrocities at 111 Taylor, a GEO Group facility, citing dysfunction and a specific incident where a mental health patient walked out and stabbed a woman. She urged the City Council to consider 'trans and/or proprietorship' of the facility.
*   Wilder Aziza, from Compton's Coalition, expressed solidarity with Melvin Balogun's family, demanding accountability from GEO Group at 111 Taylor, citing neglect, abuse, and civil rights violations. She called for a full public investigation and the closure of the facility.
*   Mohana Somebody, an Afghan American legislative aide, spoke in support of the Afghan-American Heritage Month resolution, highlighting the contributions of the Afghan diaspora.
*   Good Roti Chaudhry, Vice Chair of the Immigrant Rights Commission, spoke in strong support of the South Asian American Heritage Month resolution, emphasizing its personal significance as an immigrant and its role in affirming South Asian identity in San Francisco.
*   Hope Williams, Director of Legislative Advocacy for the Sustainable Economies Law Center, strongly supported the 'Workers Opportunity to Purchase Act', stating it gives workers the first opportunity to purchase businesses, supports worker cooperatives, and preserves local character.
*   Moussa Tarek, with CARE (Council on American-Islamic Relations), supported the South Asian American Heritage Month resolution, sharing his personal story as a Pakistani immigrant and emphasizing the community's long-standing roots and contributions in San Francisco.
*   Benji Kaplan, a unionized employee at Green Apple Books, supported the 'Workers Opportunity to Purchase Act', highlighting its role in protecting businesses from speculation and empowering workers.
*   Deva Hauser, a District Nine resident, thanked the Board for recognizing South Asian American Heritage Month, discussing the complexities of the Indian American experience and urging attention to wealth disparity and caste discrimination within the community.
*   Paula Eisner, a transactional attorney specializing in cooperatives, supported the 'Workers Opportunity to Purchase Act', calling it a 'game changer' for stabilizing communities and the city's economy, and also expressed support for justice for Melvin Balogun.
*   Joy George, an intern with the Sustainable Economies Law Center, supported the 'Workers Opportunity to Purchase Act', emphasizing its role in supporting worker self-determination and stabilizing neighborhoods.
*   Nadir Amon, a District One resident, supported the South Asian Heritage Month resolution, sharing historical examples of South Asian contributions in San Francisco and urging recognition of ongoing issues like wealth disparity and caste discrimination.
*   A speaker made comments about the deaths of Jimmy Swaggart and John MacArthur, and election rigging.
*   Jim McAfee spoke about alleged unreported incidents and deficiencies at Laguna Honda, claiming 46 pending investigations with no documented deficiencies.
*   Shaikat Chakrabarti (read by another speaker) supported the South Asian American Heritage Month resolution, emphasizing San Francisco's inclusive values but also highlighting wealth/income disparity and caste discrimination within the community.
*   Richard Askew Peterson spoke against the plan to save Muni using parcel taxes, arguing it is unfair and will create a 'war between the East Side and the West Side'.
*   Shane made comments about lawsuit settlements, personal experiences with alleged police misconduct, and living conditions, which were deemed off-topic for general public comment.
*   Mrs. Brown spoke about the unsolved murder of her son and asked for support for mothers of unsolved homicide victims, thanking Supervisor Dorsey for policies on tipsters and urging the Mayor's support.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 12 FOR ADOPTION WITHOUT COMMITTEE REFERENCE[For Adoption Boiler|B1,B2]
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary:
Items 70 through 77 were introduced for adoption without reference to committee. A unanimous vote was required for adoption of a resolution on first reading, or a member could require a resolution on first appearance to go to committee. Items 70, 71, and 74 were pulled for individual consideration.

For the balance of the items (72, 73, 75, 76, and 77), upon a roll call vote, all eleven Supervisors (Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Walton, Chan, and Chen) voted 'Aye'. With 11 Ayes and 0 Noes, these resolutions were adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250746 Adoption of Findings Related to Conditional Use Authorization - 3400 Laguna Street
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was on second appearance and had an eight-vote threshold for approval. It is a motion to adopt findings in support of the Board's disapproval of Planning Commission Motion Number 21727, approving a conditional use authorization for the proposed project at 3400 Laguna Street. This item was voted on together with Item 71. Upon a roll call vote for Items 70 and 71, Supervisors Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Walton, and Chen voted 'Aye', while Supervisor Chan voted 'No'. With 10 Ayes and 1 No, the motion was approved, meeting the eight-vote threshold.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250747 Adoption of Findings Related to Certificate of Appropriateness - 3400 Laguna Street
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This item was on second appearance and had an eight-vote threshold for approval. It is a motion adopting findings in support of the Board's disapproval of the decision of the Historic Preservation Commission by its Motion Number 494 to approve a certificate of appropriateness for the proposed project at 3400 Laguna Street. This item was voted on together with Item 70. Upon a roll call vote for Items 70 and 71, Supervisors Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Walton, and Chen voted 'Aye', while Supervisor Chan voted 'No'. With 10 Ayes and 1 No, the motion was approved, meeting the eight-vote threshold.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 250757 Afghan American Heritage Month - August 2025
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: This resolution was pulled for individual consideration. The Madam Clerk read the full title of Item 74, a resolution to declare the month of August 2025 as Afghan-American Heritage Month in the City and County of San Francisco. Supervisor Dorsey spoke in support, emphasizing the importance of formally recognizing and celebrating the cultural, civic, and economic contributions of Afghan Americans to the city, and highlighting the work of Mohana Somebody, the Board's first and only Afghan-American legislative aide. Upon a roll call vote, all eleven Supervisors (Dorsey, Engardio, Fielder, Mahmood, Randleman, Melgar, Sadr, Cheryl, Walton, Chan, and Chen) voted 'Aye'. With 11 Ayes and 0 Noes, the resolution was adopted without objection.

agenda_summaries.agenda_name: 14 ADJOURNMENT
agenda_summaries.agenda_summary: The meeting concluded with adjournments in memory of several beloved individuals: on behalf of Supervisor Dorsey and President Randleman for the late Mr. Dan Dillon; on behalf of President Randleman for the late Mr. Christopher Charles Brunetti; on behalf of Supervisor Melgar for the late Ms. Maureen Dowling; and on behalf of Supervisor Mahmood for the late Mr. Melvin Balogun. With no further business, the meeting was adjourned.
